title: northern ireland schools 2 metre rule halved
story: The Northern Ireland Executive has agreed a  metre rule is safe and appropriate for children and young people at school.⚠️ Read our coronavirus live blog for the latest news  updatesNorthern Ireland Education Minister Peter Weir sent out a letter to school principals with guidance on how they will operate once classes do start up again, according to the BBC.The move is a hint a similar relaxation of the rule could happen UK-wide.Mr Weir said in order to give schools more time to prepare, reopening for pupils has been pushed to August . Teachers will head back to schools for the original target date - August  - to get classrooms ready for students. The guidance has a day one focus that concentrates on social distancing and hygiene considerations within school settings, Mr Weir wrote. The letter said: The Northern Ireland Executive has agreed that the current social distancing guidance of m must continue to be followed between all adults within the education sector, but that a distance of m is safe and appropriate between children and young people.Using protective bubbles has been supported by the Department of Health and PHA, and flexing their use to m will allow full classes to attend.The m guidance between children is to be followed as far as possible within the confines of the physical capacity of each classroom and the m rule for staff adhered to fully.To facilitate these arrangements, schools will be opening in week commencing  August for preparation purposes, he said.Health Secretary Matt Hancock said this evening the Department for Education was looking at a relaxation for the rule in England. He said: We are working on what is needed to get all schools open in September.I do get the interaction between  metre rule and getting people back to school.But the  metre rule is itself a social distancing measure, so removing it has an impact in terms of the transmission of the disease. So we have to make sure in that review...the virus is under control enough to make the change and to replace the  metre rule,that is the conclusion, with something that makes it easier to do, for instance, getting people back to school.Northern Ireland has now dropped guidance for people who were shielding because the threat of becoming severely ill from the virus was so high. Health Minister Robin Swann said people should still be cautious when out and about and follow strict social distancing.The news comes as: Children in reception, year one and year six are currently back in schools in England, with all students expected to be back in classrooms by September.Boris Johnson announced a full review into the metre rule in England earlier this week, as hospitality industry leaders piled pressure on the PM to relax the rule. Downing Streets Chief scientic adviser Sir Patrick Vallance has said the  metre rule can be relaxed in some circumstances. title: lord alan sugar jeremy vine coronavirus
story: Voicing his thoughts on the coronavirus pandemic to Jeremy Vine, themulti millionaire implied Boris Johnson was being too cautious over lockdown restrictions. During the interview, the -year-old also claimed that no-one he knew had caught the virus, leading him to believe that the worst of the crisis was over.The Apprentice boss also suggested that the UK should follow in the footsteps of the United States and France and reopen businesses.He said: Whos dead  Im not. Im still alive. My we thank God is still alive. Sos everybody  I know. No one has caught anything. So, I suppose it is a bit of a clue there that says maybe we have reached a peak. And maybe its stime for us to follow in the example of America or indeed France that have opened up or indeed Spain.I think Prime Minister Johnson unfortunately had a problem himself and I think hes being a little too cautiousyou ask me, just slightly.Sugar, who has been living in Florida during the outbreak, said: Look, Im not a doctor and I dont want to be giving medical advice and all that stuff.The only thing I can say is Ive been here in Florida for six months and so I have lived through the cirisis, the shortage of ventilators, the no masks available, the no body wear available, the hospital beds being full up, blah blah blah. He continued: And I have now seen the transition of restaurants opening, tennis courts for example opening, golf clubsopening, restaurants opening at  percent capacity, shops have been open all the time, and quite honestly, this has been going on now for six weeks, and so I just logically say, hold on six weeks, weve come out of this so-called lockdown.One furious viewer took to Twitter to criticise the interview: Why is Alan Sugar being asked these questions in the first place  He has no expertise to offer on how to manage a public health crisis. title: rayshard brooks officer devin brosnan turns himself in
story: Officer Devin Brosnan has been accused of standing on Brooks’ shoulder as he lay dying, while fellow cop Garrett Rolfe has been charged with murder.Rolfe is accused of shooting Brooks twice in the back in a Wendy’s parking lot in Atlanta last week.Brosnan and Rolfe both arrived at the Fulton County Jail on Thursday.Brosnan has been charged with aggravated assault and violation of oath for his role in the June  death of Brooks, who was black.Officer Garrett Rolfe was charged on Wednesday as it emerged video from scene showed the victim was kicked while dying on the ground.Speaking at a press conference on Wednesday, Georgia District Attorney Paul L. Howard Jr. said warrants have been issued following the fatal shooting outside a Georgia Wendys last Friday.Brooks allegedly failed a sobriety test, took a cops taser and tried to run from authorities.Rolfe chased after Brooks and shot him in the back three times.Howard said investigators concluded officer Rolfes actions were excessive.The DA announced Rolfe is facing  charges including felony murder – which carries a possible sentence of le, le without parole, or the death penalty.Howard said Rolfe also faces several aggravated assault charges, and seven violations of office.Video showed Rolfe kicked Brooks as he fought for his le, Howard said.Brosnan faces three charges, including a count of aggravated assault and two violations of oath, the DA said.Howard said Brosnan will testy on behalf of the state – against his partner.Authorities asked for a bond of of , for Brosnan, and Rolfe is recommended to have no bond, Howard said.Brosnan bonded out of jail on Thursday afternoon, CNN reported.The DA also said one of the officers stood on [Brooks] shoulders.In the initial investigation, Howard said authorities spoke with three witnesses and reviewed eight video tapes – including two Atlanta police bodycam tapes, two dashcam tapes, a Wendy’s surveillance tape, and three citizen cellphone videos.Brooks had allegedly fallen asleep in the drivers seat of a car that was blocking the drive-through lane of Wendys around :pm.Protesters have called for justice in the incidents surrounding Brooks death.Brooks family lawyer alleged that the officers involved in the incident collected shell casings before they called for help.The officers went and put on plastic gloves and picked up their shell casings after they killed him — before rendering aid, attorney L. Chris Stewart said.“They appear to be caring more about covering their tracks than providing aid.Rolfe was fired following the incident.Brosnan, another officer involved in the incident, was put on desk duty.Howard said through the entire  minutes that Brooks was questioned, he was calm.Mr. Brooks never presented himself as a threat, Howard said.Howard said that the taser had already been fired twice when Rolfe began chasing after Brooks – and that a the weapon could only be deployed twice.It presented no danger to him, Howard said of the taser. Atlanta Police Chief Erika Shields resigned less than a day after Brooks was shot.Howard announced on Sunday that authorities had launched a homicide investigation into the incident, and that they were going over information before making a decision.Brooks death came amid ongoing protests following the death of George Floyd.Do you have a story for The US Sun team Email us at exclusive@the-sun or call   .Our journalists strive for accuracy but on occasion we make mistakes. title: uk top 10 benefit areas coronavirus impact economy
story: New stats show the number of people having to claim universal credit has leapt .million in the past three months. ⚠️ Read our coronavirus live blog for the latest news  updatesOur map reveals in many areas more than one in ten people are now having to rely on the state. The highest percentage of claimants is in Blackpool where a staggering one in eight are now in receipt of benefits. But all areas of the country have seen massive rises amid increasing concerns the country is facing its worst jobs crisis since the s. In total, .m people are now claiming unemployment benefits, an increase of .m from March, according to figures from the Office for National Statistics .Tony Wilson, director of the Institute for Employment Studies, said: If the public health crisis is just starting to ease, these figures show that the unemployment crisis is only just beginning.Its clear, too, that this crisis is hitting many poorer areas hardest.The regional impact has changed over time.According to analysis by the Centre for Cities, during the first part of lockdown unemployment rose faster in economically weaker towns and cities, but in the past month places with stronger economies have seen larger increases in claims, which suggests that the economic impact of the coronavirus outbreak has taken longer to spread south.Last week it was revealed the UK economy shrank by . per cent in April due to the coronavirus lockdown - the biggest monthly fall on record.The drop in GDP was the biggest single monthly fall since records began in , the Office for National Statisticssaid.The March plunge is also  times the average month on month decline during the global financial crisis in  , the British Chambers of Commerce said.It has also been revealed , Brits have already lost their jobs during lockdown with unemployment now set to hit three million.Experts fear the figures will in the coming months reveal the biggest drop in employment on record, laying bare the impact of the coronavirus lockdown.Early estimates from the Office for National Statistics suggest , people lost their jobs in May, on top of , the previous month.The ONS explained the numbers suggested a  per cent fall in paid employees since the country went into lockdown on March .Employment also fell by . per cent in April.The ONS deputy national economic statistician Jonathan Athow said: The slowdown in the economy is now visibly hitting the labour market, especially in terms of hours worked.Early indicators for May show that the number of employees on payrolls were down over , compared with March.Minister for Employment Mims Davies claimed the figures showed the devastation the pandemic was having on Britains workers.She said at the time: “The figures are starting to show the impact of Covid- on our economy, but our furlough scheme, grants, loans and tax cuts have protected thousands of businesses and millions of jobs, setting us up for recovery.“By responding to the needs of communities across the UK they will be at the heart of our revival and renewal, helping people find new roles and move forward with their lives.”Our journalists strive for accuracy but on occasion we make mistakes. title: madeline mcann cops letters bungle
story: The first, saying they were treating their daughter’s disappearance as murder after finding new evidence, was dispatched at the end of May.The second was sent last week to update them on the investigation, according to German prosecutor Hans Christian Wolters.Both of the notes from the German Federal Policewere sent to the McCanns indirectly via Scotland Yard.The revelation comes just days after Gerry and Kate, from Rothley, Leics, said they had not received any letters from the Germans.It again highlights the disjointed investigation which involves British, German and Portuguese police.Yesterday, The Sun told how Germany and Portugal were bickering over sharing DNA evidence that could be key to solving the case.The BKA want to test a sample of saliva found on a bedspread in the family’s holiday apartment but the Portuguese Policia Judiciaria are reluctant to hand it over.Last week, Mr Wolters revealed how “cumbersome” it was dealing with Portugal.Madeleine was three when she disappeared from the Algarve resort of Praia da Luz in May  while on holiday with her parents and her twin siblings.Two weeks ago, German authorities announced that convicted paedophile Christian B, , was their prime suspect and said they had “concrete evidence” that Madeleine was dead.In an interview with respected Italian daily la Repubblica, Mr Wolters said: “We have informed the parents family.”Christian B — who has been linked to a series of child abductions — is currently in jail for drug offences and is eligible for parole.But he also has a seven-year sentence hanging over him title: mum shock 900 packs chicken ocado
story: Hospital worker Chantelle Menzies, , spent £ on chicken thighs as part of a £ food order for her dad and family.She had it dropped at her home in Meopham, Kent, last Wednesday — but only discovered the charge on Tuesday.She said: I checked my receipt online and it was the right amount.But then I looked at my bank account afterwards and realised that Ocado had taken over £, out for my shopping.They said they have had a problem with the chicken pricing, so they charged me £ for one pack and £ for another.It is a really big amount of money - its like they charged for chicken like it was made out of gold.She was offered a refund and free delivery but said: “I was told it can take ten days. It’s not great. title: struggling schools 1bn hire tutors kids catch up
story: Ministers want to ensure the “Covid Generation” can bounce back after falling behind by missing months of school ­since lockdown began in March.⚠️ Read our coronavirus live blog for the latest news  updatesIt came as Boris Johnson faced pressure to follow Northern Ireland’s lead yesterday to halve social distancing to one metre to get more youngsters back into classes.The one-off cash package will see £million pumped into state schools in the next year. Another £million will fund tutoring for the most disadvantaged children.Heads will decide how the money will be spent but No  wants it to go on the most “effective” interventions such as small group tutoring.It can also be used to hire private tutors or extra teachers.The PM has been under pressure to act after going back on a vow to get all primary pupils back to class for a month before summer.Instead, only children in nursery, reception and Years One and Six have ed. In secondaries, only Years Ten and  are guaranteed any time in class before summer.It comes after a report revealed .million kids had done little or no schoolwork at home in lockdown.Unveiling his Covid Catch Up Plan, Mr Johnson said the money would help head teachers provide “extra support to children who have fallen behind while out of school”.In a message to parents juggling work and home schooling, he said: “I am determined to do ­everything I can to get all children back in school from September, and we’ll bring forward plans on how this will happen as soon as possible.”Education Secretary Gavin Williamson said the cash would ensure that all children will get the education, opportunities and outcomes they deserve.He said the plan would be delivered over the next academic year and bring long-term reform to education that would protect a generation of children from the effects of the pandemic.He said: “We cannot afford for any of our children to lose out as a result of Covid-.“The scale of our response must match the scale of the challenge.”Professor Becky Francis, boss of the Education Endowment Foundation charity, welcomed the money.She said: “Tutoring is the catch-up approach supported by the strongest evidence we have.“This is a tremendous opportunity to offer bespoke support for disadvantaged pupils, and build a positive legacy from the present crisis.”Meanwhile, Northern Ireland said it hoped to get all pupils back by the start of September by halving social distancing. Former Cabinet minister David Davis said the Government should look to copy the “eminently sensible” measure to get kids back to class quicker.Health Secretary Matt Hancock said the virus would have to be “under control” for England to follow suit and the two-metre rule was under review. story: The Health Secretary gave a glimmer of hope to millions of families who live far away from each other and have not been able to meet due to lockdown restrictions.⚠️ Read our coronavirus live blog for the latest news  updatesIt is currently against the law to stay overnight away from your primary residence.But Mr Hancock said ministers were looking at relaxing the rules before the end of the summer.Grilled on when the rules will be relaxed, he said: Its an important consideration, not least because I want people to be able also to have a holidayat all possible this summer.The rules currently prevent people from staying where overnight, unless they have an exceptional circumstance. So,that were looking at, and well work on it and Ill make sure that you know about the outcome of that just as soon as we possibly can.It comes as:Mr Hancock also promised that the Government would consider whether the law needs strengthening to make it easier for people to work from homethey want to.Earlier this month Boris Johnson announced changes to the lockdown allowing single adults to meet with other households.This meant those living alone or with a person under  - you can now join another household.On June , the PM revealed a new plan for support bubbles for single people living alone, who are struggling.These are currently the only people able to stay overnight under the lockdown.Current guidelines state that everyone  can now meet up in groups of six as long as they are in an outdoor space.Those not from single households must still maintain social distancingthey do meet up, and there are a number of restrictions they must abide by.Hugging is not allowed, as is sitting on the sofa, lingering inside and indoor dinner parties.You can however use the toilet during your visit, and as long as you maintain a two-metre distance, groups of up to six people from dferent households can meet outside - meaning BBQs are back on the menu.Boris urged Brits to “avoid seeing people from too many households in quick succession” and said people should keep the number of households they interact with to a minimum.He was also quick to stress that the Government will monitor the nations rate of infection and reimpose restrictionsnecessary.He warned: “We will monitor what is going on very carefully andnecessary we will reimpose measures.Those who flout coronavirus lockdown rules can be arrested by the police and fined.Fines for breaching coronavirus regulations in England will rise from £ to £, however, payment of the fine within a fortnight will reduce the sum to £ up from the present £.Those who repeatedly offend will see the fine double for each subsequent breach to a maximum of £,.  To receive The Sun’s Coronavirus newsletterevery tea time, sign up here.To follow us on Facebook, simply ‘Like’ our Coronavirus page.Get Britain’s best-selling newspaper delivered to your smartphone or tablet each day – find out more.GOT a story  RING The Sun on    or WHATSAPP on  or EMAIL exclusive@the-sunOur journalists strive for accuracy but on occasion we make mistakes. title: church of england bank apologise historic links slavery
story: The Church described its links to slavery as a “source of shame” after it was revealed scores of churches, clergymen and a bishop could have benefited from the trade by gaining compensation paid to plantation owners.⚠️ Click here for the latest news on Black Lives MatterNearly  clergymen from the Church of England are thought to have benefited from slavery according to a " rel"nofollow noreferrer noopener"database held by University College London .It was also found six governors and four directors of the Bank of England are also named as claimants or beneficiaries in the database, according to " rel"nofollow noreferrer noopener"The Daily .The names include Sir John Rae Reid, who was governor between  and  and who was also a director of the West India Co, who was paid £. million in todays money for his stake in  plantations, with , slaves, across the Caribbean.The Bank described the slave trade as “an unacceptable part of English history” and said it would block any images of its notorious former leaders from being displayed there.The UCL database has logged the details of the , people in the UK who received some of the £m – equivalent to £.billion today – which was paid in compensation under the terms of the  Abolition of Slavery Act.Three of the world’s biggest banking and insurance companies also pledged to make payments to projects benefiting black, Asian and minority ethniccommunities after their involvement in the slave trade were revealed.Royal Bank of Scotland , Lloyds Banking Group and RSA Insurance said they would be making payments or were considering doing so after they were linked to the UCL database.Insurance giant Lloyd’s of London and the brewery and pub owners Greene King said on Wednesday they would make donations to BAME causes.As well as the clergymen, the building of  churches is also linked to claimants.They include Holy Trinity in Barnstaple which, according to British History Online, was erected at an expense of nearly £,, defrayed almost wholly by the Rev. John James Scott.The Rev. John James Scott was the main beneficiary of more than £, in today’s money paid out in compensation over plantations in Jamaica which belonged to his father.Other clergymen who benefited from the compensation scheme were brothers Rev George Trevelyan and Rev John Thomas Trevelyan, of Somerset.Along with other family members, they received more than £m in todays money when they had to give up six estates in Grenada, which they inherited from their father, where more than , people were enslaved.The compensation cash was paid to the clergymen rather than the church itself.The Church of England had campaigned for the abolition of slavery in the early s and issued an apology for historic cases in .A Church of England spokesman said: We are unfamiliar with this data, but slavery and exploitation have no place in society. While we recognise the leading role clergy and active members of the Church of England played in securing the abolition of slavery, it is a source of shame that others within the church actively perpetrated slavery and profited from it.A Bank of England spokesman said: As an institution, the Bank was never itself directly involved in the slave trade, but is aware of some inexcusable connections involving former governors and directors and apologises for them.The Bank has commenced a thorough review of its collection of images of former governors and directors to ensure none with any such involvement in the slave trade remain on display anywhere in the Bank.Our journalists strive for accuracy but on occasion we make mistakes. title: air bridges boris june
story: The bridges could allow Brits to skip quarantine when arriving back in the UK after travelling, as well as any isolation requirements in the selected countries.This could include Greece, Portugal and Spain, as well as overseas UK territories including Bermuda, the British Virgin Islands and Gibraltar. The Foreign Office is also expected to relax its guidance against Brits making any non-essential travel abroad.An source told The : “The plan is to announce a small number of air bridges on June , though it won’t come into force until July .“Obviously it will depend on factors such as the scientic advice and the level of coronavirus infections at the time.June  is the date for the Governments first review of its controversial quarantine policy, which came into force last week.The Health Secretary Matt Hancock confirmed to Radio s Today programme yesterday that the government is close to introducing travel corridors with certain countries soon - meaning there would be no need for travellers to quarantine on arrival in the UK. Mr Hancock said: Thats the plan. The quarantine policy is important because there are some countries around the world where this virus is not under control, however, theres other countries where it may be safe to be able to not have a quarantine in place.So ahead of the formal review of the quarantine arrangements on the th of June, Im working with Grant Shapps on whether there are countries that have a low rate of infection where we can come to an agreement on a travel corridor.Travel between the UK and France will also be raised in a meeting between the two countries this week, Boris Johnson has said.The Prime Minister is believed to have talked with French president Emmanuel Macron about how people can move safely between the two countries when Mr Macron came to Britain yesterday.He also reiterated that air bridges, enabling holidaymakers to travel overseas without entering self-isolation when they , were being considered.It comes after Transport Secretary Grant Shapps indicated that the Government is actively working on introducing travel corridors, to help the struggling tourism industry.Speaking at Tuesdays Downing Street press conference, Mr Johnson said: Obviously I will be talking to Emmanuel Macron about all sorts of ways in which we can bring our countries together, making sure that eventually we will be able to travel freely to and from each others countries.The same goes obviously for Spain, as soon as we can.The reason for having the quarantine system is very simple - we dont want to re-import the disease just at the moment when weve really got it under control in this country.But were certainly looking at air bridges and ways to ensure that people can safely go on holiday eventually.Most international arrivals into the UK are required to go into self-isolation for  days, while in France, a two-week quarantine is currently in place for UK visitors.Earlier on Tuesday, Mr Shapps told LBC radio: We wont be in a position to announce which countries - where reciprocal arrangements go in place - until the th.So dont expect anything this week, I think Im right in saying its only the end of next week.All passengers, bar a handful of exemptions, have to fill out an online locator form giving their contact and travel details, as well as the address of where they will isolate.Mr Shapps said the measure was introduced because we dont want to go back to kind of importingor Brits going abroad and bringing it back with them.A group of more than  travel and hospitality businesses campaigning against the policy said last week they had received private assurances from senior Government sources that travel corridors will be in place from June .Spain has warned that it may impose its own -day quarantine requirement for UK tourists.Foreign affairs minister Arancha Gonzalez Laya told the BBCs Hardtalk programme: We will be checking what the UK will be doing and we will be in dialogue with the UK to see whether or not we should be introducing reciprocity as they have dferent measures than the rest of the EU.She added: The health situation ... is a little bit better in Spain than it is in the UK.This came after Spains prime minister Pedro Sanchez announced over the weekend that tourists from many European nations would be welcome from June .A number of other countries on the continent eased their border restrictions on Monday, but many have maintained entry restrictions for UK holidaymakers.Destinations that do not require UK holidaymakers to enter quarantine include Belgium, Portugal, Italy and Switzerland.Airline trade body the International Air Transport Association said rapid Covid- testing of passengers from countries considered as higher risk could remove the need for burdensome and intrusive measures such as quarantine.Our journalists strive for accuracy but on occasion we make mistakes. title: brits staycations wales
story: The country will officially open its borders to tourism, First Minister Mark Drakeford announced.⚠️ Read our coronavirus live blog for the latest news  updatesIts another boost for Brits hoping to go on holiday this after it was announced air bridges are expected to be introduced on July .Wales will scrap its stay local guidance Monday July  as long as it it safe to do so.Brits from England will be able to travel to Wales and stay in self-contained accommodation including holiday cottages, static caravans and some hotels. He told BBC Radio  Live: On Monday  July, provided the virus is still under control, we will lt our stay local instruction here in Wales and at that point the tourism economy will reopen in Wales.I’ve got to caveat it by saying we’ve got to be sure the virus is still under control at that point.Provided it is, the stay local restrictions will be abolished [on July ] and people inside Wales and from outside Wales will be able to travel.I’ll be saying today to our tourism sector that they should use the next three weeks to prepare so that beyond that, self-contained accommodation will be able to reopen in Wales.People will be able to travel to holiday cottages or static caravans or hotels that are organised on a self-contained basis.And people will be able to take bookings in Wales on July  onwards.Mr Drakeford is preparing announce the latest measures to ease lockdown after effectively shutting the Welsh borders to England. Under current measures, Brits in England are not allowed to stay overnight - but that could change within weeks as the country looks to reopen the hospitality sector from July .And in Wales people have been told not to travel more than five miles, which will be scrapped from July .In Scotland, the hospitality sector isnt set to start reopening until at least July .Yesterday, Nicola Sturgeon revealed the latest lockdown relaxations, including letting people meet two other households outdoors but pubs and cafes will remain shuttered.The Republic of Ireland has is lting some restrictions on travel, with journeys up to  miles allowed from June .However, Leo Varadkar is looking to form air bridges with countries where Covid- has been controlled.For the UK, air bridges could be introduced on July .The bridges could allow Brits to skip quarantine when arriving back in the UK after travelling, as well as any isolation requirements in the selected countries.This could include Greece, Portugal and Spain, as well as overseas UK territories including Bermuda, the British Virgin Islands and Gibraltar.The Foreign Office is also expected to relax its guidance against Brits making any non-essential travel abroad.Our journalists strive for accuracy but on occasion we make mistakes. title: covid alert level 3 uk
story: Health Secretary Matt Hancock described the move as “big moment for the country” and praised Brits’ determination to beat the disease.⚠️ Read our coronavirus live blog for the latest news  updatesThe Government’s chief medical officers, led by Prof Chris Whitty, say transmission of the bug is no longer high or rising exponentially.It prompted the Joint Biosecurity Centre to advise ministers they could reduce the alert level from four to three on their five-point scale.This allows for a “gradual relaxation of restrictions and social distancing measures” - raising hopes that the two-metre rule could be eased.It comes as:Sources say it has no immediate implications but gives ministers confidence they can take further steps towards ending lockdown at the start of July.This is likely to include reducing the two metre social distancing rule and allowing pubs, restaurants and cafes to reopen.The Government has been under pressure to scrap the strict measure by schools and the hospitality sector who are worried they cannot fully reopen.Mr Hancock said: “The UK moving to a lower alert level is a big moment for the country, and a real testament to the British peoples determination to beat this virus.“The Governments plan is working.“Infection rates are rapidly falling, we have protected the NHS and, thanks to the hard work of millions in our health and social care services, we are getting the country back on her feet.”A joint statement from the CMOs said: “The Joint Biosecurity Centre has recommended that the Covid- alert level should move from Level to Level  .“There has been a steady decrease in cases we have seen in all four nations, and this continues.“It does not mean that the pandemic is over. The virus is still in general circulation, and localised outbreaks are likely to occur.“We have made progress against the virus thanks to the efforts of the public and we need the public to continue to follow the guidelines carefully to ensure this progress continues.”  The Prime Minister unveiled the five-stage coronavirus warning system as part of a gradual easing of the lockdown during a televised address on May .He said he was establishing a new joint biosecurity centreto run the alert system, which is similar to that used to establish the terrorist threat.The group would detect increases in Covid- infection rates and judge how strict lockdown measures and social distancing rules should be.Two factors determine the UKs coronavirus threat level - the R number and the number of confirmed Covid- infections at any one time.The alert levels range from level one - green - to level five - red.When the scheme was launched, the country was at level four, which means a Covid- epidemic is in general circulation, transmission is high or rising exponentially.The system says that current social distancing measures and restrictions should remain in place.Level five is when transmission is high or rising but also when there was a risk of healthcare services being overwhelmed and will require an increase in social distancing measures.Level one means Covid- is no longer known to be in the UK and the only action should be routine international monitoring.Level three is when the epidemic is in general circulation and gradual easing of restrictions can take place, while level two is when the number of cases and transmission is low and no or minimal restrictions are required.But under level two there will be enhanced testing, tracing, monitoring and screening.At the end of May, Mr Johnson told MPs that were coming down the Covid alert system from level four to level three tomorrow, we hope, were going to be taking a decision tomorrow.But the alert level was not lowered - despite the easing of some restrictions - and it remained at four until now.Representatives from industries, such as the hospitality sector, may hope it could also pave the way for the two-metre rule to be relaxed which is key for many pubs, restaurants and cafes to reopen.Prof Matt Keeling, of Warwick University, believes the downgrade is currently justied but cautions against the easing of social distancing.He said: The move to level three is not a time for complacency, there is still the prospect of a second wavecontrols are relaxed too quickly and the reproductive numberrises above one.We are likely to be entering a new phase of this outbreak, where nationally and regionally cases will continue to decline, but locally there will be isolated clusters of cases that need to be contained.To receive The Sun’s Coronavirus newsletterevery tea time, sign up here.To follow us on Facebook, simply ‘Like’ our Coronavirus page.Get Britain’s best-selling newspaper delivered to your smartphone or tablet each day – find out more.Our journalists strive for accuracy but on occasion we make mistakes. title: tensions north korea south korea
story: On Wednesday North Korea said it would redeploy troops after rejecting the South’s offer to send special envoys to ease tensions.North Korea said it would send troops to inter-Korean cooperation sites on its territory, rebuild guard posts and restart military drills at the northern side of the border with South Korea. The news, which was reported by state news agency KCNA, would nully the  deals that ban both Koreas from taking any hostile acts against each other.A spokesman for the General Staff of theKorean People’s Armysaid the country would dispatch troops to Mount Kumgang and Kaesong near the border.Police posts that were withdrawn from the Demilitarized Zone will be reinstalled, while artillery units near the western sea border would be reinforced with the alert heightened to the level of “top-class combat duty”, the spokesman said. This comes days after Pyongyang destroyed the joint liaison office that had been set up in the border town of Kaesong as part of their peace agreements. On Monday South Korea’s President, Moon Jae-in offered to send his national security adviser, Chung Eui-yong, and spy chief Suh Hoon to Pyongyang as special envoys. However, Kim Jong-un’s sister and government official Kim Yo Jong “flatly rejected the tactless and sinister proposal” according to KCNA.She also accused Moon of using envoy’s to tide over crises and suggesting “preposterous proposals.”KCNA said: “The solution to the present crisis between the North and the South caused by the incompetence and irresponsibility of the South Korean authorities is impossible and it can be terminated only when the proper price is paid.In response, President Moon’s office said that the South would no longer accept “unreasonable behaviour” by the North.South Korea’s defence ministry warned of the dangers of military actions saying.Jeon Dong-jin, the director of operations at the Joint Chiefs of Staff, said: “These moves thwart two decades of efforts by South and North Korea to improve inter-Korean relations and to keep peace on the Korean peninsular.If the North actually takes such a move, it will certainly pay the price for it.The KPA said on Tuesday it had been studying an action plan to re-enter zones that had been demilitarised under a  inter-Korean military pact and turn the front line into a fortress.Seouls defence ministry has urged North Korea to abide by the agreement, under which both sides agreed to cease all hostile acts and dismantled a number of structures along the DMZ. Despite rising tensions, South Korea said on Thursday that it hadn’t detected any suspicious activities by North Korea. Kim Jun-rak, a spokesman at Seoul’s Joint Chiefs of Staff, told reporters that there have been no signs indicating North Korea had started to carry out its threats. He said South Korea will maintain a firm military readiness to deal with any situations.Our journalists strive for accuracy but on occasion we make title: scrap two metre rule schools
story: Chair of the Education Select Committee MP Robert Halfon has called on ministers to put schools first in line to have the social distancing rule relaxed after Northern Ireland cut the rule to  metre for schools. ⚠️ Read our coronavirus live blog for the latest news  updatesMr Halfon told The Sun: What they should do is possibly have dferent social distancing rules for dferent organisations.  might be able to be relaxed a bit in schools because there is low transmission of risk, so with low transmissionslightly dferent rules in dferent places.He said he hoped schools would be first on the list for a relaxation of the social distancing rule because it could allow more schools to come back. Documents released by the Scientic Advisory Group for Emergencieshave shown children are less likely to pass on coronavirus.Mr Halfon added: However kids go backis going to make them feel better, theyll be with their friends and socialising and learning. Its incredibly important and I would welcome any kind of . The Tory MP cautioned he believed the UK should follow the science when it came to changing social distancing rules. You can unsubscribe at any time.Thank you for subscribingWe have more newslettersShow meSee ourprivacy noticeInvalid EmailThe UKaposs coronavirus alert level has finally been reduced today for the first time since lockdown. The four Chief Medical Officers for the four nations of the UK agreed it should be reduced from Level  to Level . It means the Covid- epidemic is in general circulation, but transmission is no longer high or rising exponentially. Itaposs finally happened after the government claimed for weeks that it was moving towards . Health Secretary Matt Hancock boasted it is a big moment for the country, and a real testament to the British people’s determination to beat this virus. But it doesnapost actually make much dference to how the UK will come out of lockdown. Thataposs because after a massive row over the alert level, the government claimed it doesnapost actually make a dference to easing restrictions. So what is the alert level and what dference will todayaposs announcement make to your le  Weaposve had a took. What are the coronavirus alert levels   There are five alert levels, set by a Joint Biosecurity Centre that was established in May to deal with the pandemic. They are:Level  COVID- is not known to be present in the UK Level  COVID- is present in the UK, but the number of cases and transmission is low Level  A COVID- epidemic is in general circulation Level  A COVID- epidemic is in general circulation transmission is high or rising exponentially Level  As level  and there is a material risk of healthcare services being overwhelmedWhat is the UK Covid- alert level now  As of Friday  June the alert level is three, meaning a COVID- epidemic is in general circulation. That is down from level four, as the alert level had been since the system was set up in May. Who agrees the UK alert level   Changes to the alert level are recommended by the JBC and then signed off by the four Chief Medical Officers in the four nations of the UK. In other words, despite Boris Johnson claiming for weeks that it was moving towards , he does not have direct power to change the alert level. The level is set primarily by R - the number of new people each carrier is infecting - and the overall number of coronavirus cases. What is the alert level actually used for   Thereaposs a big debate about some of this. We know from the roadmap for easing lockdown, published on May , that the alert level is designed to communicate the current level of risk clearly to the public. So itaposs a bit like the terror threat level. It crunches of all the risks facing the UK into one star rating, to give the public a vague idea of how bad things are. It shows the threat now - not the potential future threatthe virus spins out of control again. Whataposs controversial is how much the alert level affects lockdown directly. When it was first announced in May, the government said there was a link - but now it claims there isnapost a link at all. What did the government say before   When the alert level system was set up in May, the government linked it to the easing of lockdown. In a slide on May  , is said that at level , current social distancing measures and restrictions remain. Only at level  would there be a gradual relaxing of restrictions and social distancing measures. And at level  there would be no or minimal social distancing measures. And Boris Johnson said on May : That Covid Alert Level will tell us how tough we have to be in our social distancing measures – the lower the level the fewer the measures. The higher the level, the tougher and stricter we will have to be.  The government has since changed its tune and made clear any changes to lockdown are not based on the alert level. Instead, No says lockdown changes are based on the five tests for easing lockdown:The NHS is able to cope A sustained fall in deaths New infections dropping enough Adequate testing and PPE No risk of a second peak that overwhelms NHSThis prompted a massive row when the government started easing lockdown in England - opening schools and shops, and letting groups of six meet outdoors - despite the high alert level. Questioned on June , the PMaposs spokesman appeared to rewrite history. He said the government were always clear that changes to lockdown were based on the separate five tests - not the alert levels. Why did the row happen  We still donapost fully know. Perhaps itaposs possible that early No literature - including Boris Johnsonaposs address to the nation - was produced in error or when the policy wasnapost properly settled. But what we do know is this. Using the five tests, rather than the alert level, allowed some political input into the decision to ease lockdown. Rather than basing it entirely on the science about the virus, Boris Johnson could also base his decision on other factors like the economy. We also know it took a long time for the Joint Biosecurity Centre - which sets the alert level - to be ready. On June , three weeks after it was announced, No admitted the Joint Biosecurity Centre was not yet fully up and running”. What dference will it make to lockdown

You can unsubscribe at any time.Thank you for subscribingWe have more newslettersShow meSee ourprivacy noticeInvalid EmailA blind woman shielding alone has told how coronavirus left her unable to even speak as she desperately called  for an ambulance. Elizabeth Manuel, , was forced to shut herself off from the world when the government announced vulnerable people and the over s should not leave home for  weeks. She lost her sight after suffering a near fatal brain hemorrhage and stroke at the age of . But as millions of people raced to the supermarket and selfishly stripped shelves of essentials - Elizabeth became one of the unfortunate needy Brits left without basic supplies.As she shielded at her Portsmouth home soon after the country entered lockdown - she was then struck down with coronavirus.Describing her terrying ordeal, Elizabeth said the virus choked her of breath as she desperately tried to call  for an ambulance.Follow all coronavirus updates on our live blog hereShe said: I was one of the first people in early March told to self-isolate - from that point on I had no contact with anyone as I live completely on my own. I then went from the vulnerable to the extremely vulnerable category. And to add to the excitement, I ended up being diagnosed with coronavirus. I started off with a headache and then had a persistent cough that went into bad breathing dficulties. After  hours I knew I needed some urgent help and I had to call  because I simply could not breath. But I couldnapost even ask for an ambulance - I had no breath to speak and I had to press buttons to identy where I was. I then went to open the door for paramedics as I thought I could lose consciousness before they arrived. Elizabeth was admitted to hospital for three nights as she recovered from the worst part of her illness.  But after being confirmed well enough to go home, she ed to her empty house - struggling to get out of bed for three weeks while panicking about where her food was going to come from. Elizabeth, who despite her own blindness and lockdown struggles, signed up as an NHS volunteer in the hope of helping from home, also spoke about her struggles with supermarkets shops and deliveries. As supplies in her cupboards and fridge dwindled, Elizabeth panicked about how she would feed herself without any help. Despite writing to supermarkets, her local MP and local crisis groups, Elizabeth said she was made to feel worthless when nobody offered immediate help. She said: I knew I really needed food so tried internet shopping but there were no slots. Every day I would go online and there would be no slots, I was getting very axious. I wrote to the supermarkets because at that point there was nothing in terms of a priority slot. Then under government rules I went from being vulnerable to extremely vulnerable.  I was contacting people telling them I had about a weekaposs worth of food in my freezer and that was it. It made me feel worthless and one of the worst things about lockdown is I have felt more disabled now than i ever have since having my stroke. Elizabeth also said her anxiety about ing to the outside world after lockdown ends is also much higher. Describing the complexities of navigating outside under normal circumstances, Elizabeth said she is now even more anxious at the thought of having to social distance. She said: My independence has changed in terms of my anxiety levels are high. My blindness means over half the world doesnapost exist to me and going out as a blind person is more scary anyway.

You can unsubscribe at any time.Thank you for subscribingWe have more newslettersShow meSee ourprivacy noticeInvalid EmailCats and dogs could be carrying coronavirus which could spark a second wave of the killer bug experts have warned. Pet owners in the UK are being urged to get their much loved furry ones tested amid fears they can contract the virus, incubate it and pass it on to humans.This puts the country at risk of a fresh outbreak evencoronavirus has been wiped out in humans, itaposs claimed.There have been conflicting reports since the pandemic began about whether pets pose any coronavirus risk or not. Now researchers from University College London want a mass surveillance programme of all animals that live close to humans. Professor Joanne Santini wants more research into which animals are susceptible to Covid- and increased testing.  She wrote in the The Lancet Microbe medical journal: There is increasing evidence that some animals can catch SARS-CoV- from people, and might subsequently transmit it to other people - but we donapost know just how much of a risk this is, as itaposs an area of study that has not yet been prioritised.We need to develop surveillance strategies to ensure we donapost get taken by surprise by a large outbreak in animals, which could pose a threat not just to animal health but to human health as well. Virus transmission in animal populations could become irreversibleleft unchecked, and may threaten the success of existing public health measurespeople continue to catch the virus from an infected population of animals. Colleague Professor Sarah Edwards added: “There’s an urgent need for widespread surveillance, by testing samples, preferably non-invasively, from large numbers of animals, particularly pets, livestock and wildle that are in close proximity to human populations.”  More laboratory experiments on small numbers of animals are unlikely to give us the evidence needed to be confident that certain species are entirely safe, making major surveillance work the only real option here. Previous studies have hinted that Covid- could be transmitted to animals because the protein it depends upon is found in many species. Domestic and feral cats, dogs, hamsters, monkeys and ferrets have so far been shown to be able to be infected with the virus. Researchers say farmed wildle such as pigs, minks, bats and rodents, could act as reservoir species for the virus.  It can be hard to identysome animals are carrying the virus because while some will show symptoms others will be asymptomatic. If an animal tests positive for coronavirus they will need to be quarantined or culled. In Holland , farmed minks were killed after they became infected with the virus and passed it on to two humans. Experts believe that, once originally infected by humans, the outbreak spread to dferent farms through feral cats.  Tests discovered a signicant minority of cats had been infected with the virus. The US Centres for Disease Control and Prevention acknowledges that cats, dogs “and a few other” animals can be infected. The organisation has updated its advice telling people not to let their pets interact with other animals or people outside the house. In New York Nadia, a four-year-old Malaysian tiger, contracted coronavirus at Bronx Zoo reportedly from a keeper.

You can unsubscribe at any time.Thank you for subscribingWe have more newslettersShow meSee ourprivacy noticeInvalid EmailAn eerie abandoned farmhouse left frozen in time provided one photographer with a fascinating look into rural le more than  years ago. The home in County Tyrone, Northern Ireland, looks ordinary from the outside, but inside it is packed with newspapers dating back to , stopped clocks, a half-smoked pipe, and the owneraposs shoes left by the bed years after the property was vacated. Photographer Rebecca was invited in to see the decaying cottage after its owner died and she was left in awe of the haunting scenes within the perfectly preserved home. The cottage was lived in until  by the last of three brothers, who kept all of their family history, alongside tins of food from the early th century left unopened on the kitchen shelves.A man only identied as Dessie was the last to live there, leading aposa solitary le among the relics of the pastapos before moving into a home in  and passing away two years later. Rebecca, who owns the Abandoned NI website sharing photos of the derelict houses she explores, was allowed in by the owner to get a record of the incredible space before it was knocked down to make way for a new build. She said she was left gobsmacked by what she found, with old books, magazines, papers and photographs littered around the farm workeraposs cottage and left untouched. A clock on the mantel piece is stuck showing ., a pair of glasses are left ready to pick up and a rusted OXO tin has been left open, with two pocket watches stored inside. Hundreds of handwritten letters fill the drawers, and three kettles are sat on the stove, next to a cup which appears to have been placed there just before it was abandoned. Old books and newspapers including the Mid Ulster Mail from  were left sitting in the living room which had been shut off for more than  years, alongside one newspaper which reported the aftermath of the sinking of the Titanic in . Upstairs there remained rotting bedclothes, a bed pan on the floor and a flat cap left hanging on the end of a bedframe. Rebecca said she initially wasnapost surethe interior would be very interesting, but she has now created an exhibition based on the lives of Dessie and his family.  She said: I have to admit I saw the outside and wasnapost sureit was worth it. As soon as I opened the door I was blown away. I went into what I thought was a wee cottage and itaposs basically a social history museum. The cottage first appeared on maps in  and Rebecca began researching the family to help piece together the puzzle in all of the photographs. After talking to people to find out more about Dessie, she said: Among many things he was a fabulous cook, many friends still talk about his famous soda bread which he cooked over the original stove. He was a hearty farmer, milking cows to produce milk and butter.It was reportedyou stayed for dinner in the house and you finished up, you were given another dinner for seconds.No one left with an empty stomach. One of the mysteries Rebecca was able to solve was personal items belonging to an Edwin McQueen, who she was able to discover was married to Dessieaposs mum. He worked as a policeman, and a certicate from  and a framed picture of him in his unorm was found in one of the bedrooms.

title: my tiny baby same condition
story: NewsMy tiny baby has same condition as alcoholics and needs a second liver transplantKamiesha Kelly and her partner Dakarai Ryan were over the moon when they found out they were expecting daughter, Milly, but when she was just four months old she was given a devastating diagnosisShareCommentsByJamie Blue MountainJane LavenderAssistant Editor:,  JUN Updated:,  JUN NewsLittle Milly was diagnosed with a rare liver condition at just four months old " to FREE email alerts from Mirror - daily newsSubscribeWhen you subscribe we will use the information you provide to send you these newsletters. Sometimes they’ll include recommendations for other related newsletters or services we offer. OurPrivacy Noticeexplains more about how we use your data, and your rights. You can unsubscribe at any time.Thank you for subscribingWe have more newslettersShow meSee ourprivacy noticeInvalid EmailWhen Kamiesha Kelly found out she was pregnant with daughter, Milly, it was a happy surprise for her and partner Dakarai Ryan. When their gorgeous little girl was born in January last year, weighing lb oz, the couple were over the moon. But just four months later their joy turned to despair when they were told she was battling the rare liver condition biliary atresia. The illness only affects young children butleft untreated can lead to liver cirrhosis, which is most common among people with alcohol addiction. Millyaposs only hope was a liver transplant. Kamiesha only realised she was pregnant when she noticed she was more emotional than usual. The -year-old from Edmonton, in North London, said: I wouldnapost have suspected I was pregnantit wasnapost for my emotions being all over the place. I was getting very upset and crying a lot. I went to cancel my internet service one evening. I had to pay a leaving fee and I was crying my eyes out down the phone to my provider. I knew something was wrong after that and remembered having a similar breakdown when I was pregnant before. So, two days later, I bought a pregnancy test. After the fourth one was positive, I finally believed it. It was a surprise - but a pleasant surprise. And when I told Dakarai the next morning, he couldnapost stop smiling. For the whole day he had this huge smile on his face. Devoted mum Kamiesha, who has an older daughter, Aniyah, six, from a previous relationship, was plagued with morning sickness throughout her pregnancy and her labour was extremely tough. She explained: They tried everything to get her out. After three tanks of air and an epidural she finally came. She was seemingly happy and healthy and the next day we were out of there. But little Milly was far from a contented baby and Kamiesha says she would scream the house down and was always hungry. Kamiesha put it down to her daughter being a little grouchy. She said: Milly would just cry and scream all day long. She refused to nap and was always up.No matter how much we fed her she was never satisfied. Then, when Milly was a month old the whites of her eyes took on a dull yellow tinge which turned turned full on yellow within a week. Kamiesha said: They were yellow like the shining sun.The worried mum called NHS  and was told to see her GP, who thought she was suffering from acid reflux and prescribed Gaviscon - an over the counter heartburn and indigestion remedy - to be mixed with her baby milk.Kamiesha said: The doctor wasnapost worried about the colour of her eyes. She said it was quite common in newborns. But Millyaposs condition didnapost improve over the next few weeks and her aunt, Natalie, offered to pay for a private consultation with a paediatrician. Kamiesha and her delivery driver partner will never forget the day that changed their lives forever. She said: After feeling her stomach the doctor turned to us and said, aposI need a few minutes.apos He came back in the room and asked us to sit down. I knew then it was serious and, at that point, I was hysterical. They were told Milly had suspected biliary atresia - which affects just . in , births in England and Wales. The condition occurs when the liveraposs bile ducts become blocked and without treatment it leads to scarring of the liver, or cirrhosis, most commonly caused by prolonged alcohol abuse. Blood and urine tests at their local AE confirmed their worst fears. Kamiesha said: When they told us Milly needed a new liver, I was in a flood of tears. All I could think was, aposWhy is this happening  Why canapost it be straight forward apos It was actually heartbreaking. But, with no organ immediately available, doctors remained hopeful that they could still help Milly. She was booked in for surgery five days later, where they hoped to re-establish the flow of bile from the liver. Heartbreakingly, less than an hour into the three-hour operatio, Kamiesha received the gut wrenching news that her daughteraposs liver was already too damaged for the surgery to work.. While Milly spent the next three days recovering in hospital her parents were told she would now need a new liver to have any hope of surviving. For the next eight months Milly was given eight tablets a day – a combination of steroids, pain relief and vitamins - while she waited for an organ match. Kamiesha said: Those were the hardest eight months of my le. Milly was in so much pain, her stomach kept getting bigger and bigger. It felt like weaposd had all the special moments of her first year with us stolen. Then, in October last year, the family got the news they had been desperately hoping for - a liver match had been found and Milly was rushed to hospital by ambulance. Kamiesha said: I couldnapost control myself - I was crying with joy. Every emotion you can think of was running through my body. We were all so excited for her and she didnapost even know - she was too young to understand. After seven hours of surgery the operation was hailed a success and Milly spent the next month in hospital recovering from the massive procedure. Discharged on November , , for the next few months she seemed to be going from strength to strength. Kamiesha said: Everything was going okay. Milly started doing the things sheaposd missed out on, like sitting on the sofa on her own and babbling. But the Milly and her family were dealt a devastating blow in February. Blood tests at a routine check-up showed her liver was not ing properly and for the next two months doctors did their best to stabilise her by increasing the her anti-rejection drugs. Despite their best efforts, a biopsy from Millyaposs liver in April confirmed her body was rejecting the donor organ, seeing aof the totaposs extended stomach.  Still waiting to hear the next step in her daughteraposs treatment, Kamiesha said: Because of lockdown the doctors have pushed back Millyaposs review, which will tell us exactly what the next steps are. Worst case scenario, she is going to be relisted for a new liver and Iaposm not sure we can go through that again. Now the couple have launched a GoFundMe page, hoping to raise £, to fund treatment outside the NHSneeded. It was only going private that ended up getting Milly diagnosed in the first place and even then it was too late, Kamiesha said. She was putting on weight and seemed to be responding well. We knew something was wrong with Milly when she was just a month old.

The -year-old posted a photo of herself covered in colourful squares and what looks like cream cake in a celebratory post early this morning. The youngest ever Nobel Prize laureate also shared a snap of her and her family posing with balloons and a large cake which reads: Happy graduation Malala. She wrote: Hard to express my joy and gratitude right now as I completed my Philosophy, Politics and Economics degree at Oxford.I don’t know what’s ahead. Universities across the country have closed to students and non-essential staff, meaning exams could not go ahead as usual. The typically raucous celebrations expected after an intense exam season have also not been able to go ahead, with graduates like Malala having to toast their successes at home instead. The human rights activist came to the worldaposs attention when she was  and a blog she had written about le as a girl in Taliban-controlled Swat Valley caught the eye of journalist Adam B. Ellick. Eight years ago a Taliban gunman attempted to assassinate her for her activism, plunging the then -year-old into a critical condition with a bullet to the head. She was transferred to a hospital in Birmingham, UK where she recovered before setting up a le in the country.Malala co-authored the best-selling book aposI am Malalaapos in  and jointly won the  Nobel Peace Prize along with Kailash Satyarthi. Hundreds of people flocked to wish the young woman well upon news of her graduation from Lady Margaret Hall.Astronaut and former USA national rugby player Anne McClain wrote: Congratulations on your graduation @Malala! title: dark blues trio bow down gordon strachan jimmy nicholl gary irvine
story: Gary Irvine has revealed the relationships between himself, Dundee coach Dave Mackay and manager James McPake are built on trust.But the Dee’s U  coach admits that, when it comes to knowledge, all three bow down to Gordon Strachan and Jimmy Nicholl.Irvine, Mackay and McPake are a tight-knit group at Dens.Their friendships are long-standing.But Irvine says the trio’s working relationship has been boosted by the input of veteran coaches Strachan, currently Dundee’s technical director, and Jimmy Nicholl, McPake’s assistant.Irvine said: “We have a good relationship with each other, me and [Dave Mackay] at Dundee.“I’m obviously really close with the manager, we’re from the same area, Airdrie, and have known each other since high school.“We’ve always kept in touch and since being team-mates at Dundee have driven up together.“Going into the manager’s job, James has always said he needed people around him he could trust and its important to have good people around the place. Players pick up on that.“Having Gordon Strachan and Jimmy Nicholl’s experience is fantastic as well.“We might have our playing experience but they have  years more experience in the game than any of us. That’s invaluable.”Irvine and Mackay work closely together at Dundee – but it’s not the first time they have worked together.Dee first team coach, Mackay, was brought to St Johnstone by Derek McInnes while Irvine was the Perth side’s first choice right back.In the end, Mackay went on to be come a club legend at McDiarmid, while Irvine moved on to Dundee.But there are no hard feelings from Irvine, who has loved every minute of his time at Dens Park.He said: “Dave Mackay came in from Livingston in [St Johnstone’s] first season in the SPL to add competition for places. I was unfortunate because I’d chosen to have surgery to tidy up an ankle problem that had niggled me.“The plan was that would tie in with the close season and I could start pre-season.“But it hindered me and I was behind with my fitness and struggled a bit to get back to form.“Dave, obviously, came in and did well and I think him being able to play in a few positions helped him, too.“I recognised at that time, being in my mid-s I wanted to be playing every week and I wouldn’t get that at St Johnstone.“I’ve nothing against Del, that’s the decisions that have to be made to win games – when Dave came in, the manager couldn’t guarantee me games and I heard there was interest from Dundee.”For as little as £. a month you can access all of our content, including Premium articles. blaize_config   n t t tCancelation Offer % - Web + ePaperGet unlimited access to the Eveningwebsite and Premium Content and all the benefits of the print paper in a digital replica of the Evening  n t t t t n t t t ua. per month  u recurring subscription n n t t t n t t t tEdition: n t t t tWeb + ePaper n t t t n t t t n t tSubscribe TodayEnjoy the digital edition of the Eveningnewspaper on your smartphone, tablet and computer.Unlimited access to all articles on the Eveningwebsite. title: lee wilkie dundee united scottish football lucky dundee fc wait
story: Making it work will no doubt be a massive task but Dundee United are one of Scottish football’s lucky ones as they ed to pre-season training this week.United and their  Premiership counterparts were able to get back on the pitch for the first time in three months with the Terrors conducting some socially-distanced sessions yesterday.Shaking off the cobwebs and getting back to it after a normal post-season break is hard enough but in coronavirus times it’s an altogether dferent task.Tangerines gaffer Robbie Neilson will still want to run the rule over his charges’ fitness levels as he plots how to tackle their first season at the top table in four years.Robbie will also be looking to see where he can strengthen in the transfer window with he and his staff working on the technical and tactical side of their game, too.The day-to-day challenges of the Covid- pandemic makes doing these things all the more dficult, however.There will be government, SFA and SPFL guidelines United will need to followwe are to continue to move towards the planned August  start date for the new top-flight campaign.Although that will be giving all at Tannadice a huge headache, just being able to get some sort of normality back to things will be a relief.It’s a massive step for the club and the first small one in getting back to proper football.They will have been stagnating for the past wee while and I can assure you the players will have been stirring in their houses raring to go.Robbie, too, will be champing at the bit to get his team how he wants it.You’d imagine small-sided matches between the squad and bounce games, when it’s safe to do, will go a long way in doing that.Jumping up to the Premiership, they’ll need to find that competitive edge again.It’s a big step for the club and one they’ve worked hard to achieve over the past couple of years.They won’t want anything to scupper their chance to shine on the big stage and will be leaving no stone unturned.I don’t think they are far away from being able to challenge for the top six with the players they have but a couple of quality additions would certainly go a long way to boosting morale.With , season ticket holders behind them, too, things are looking up again for United.Nobody, not least Dundee and their manager James McPake, will have wanted it to go this way.However, starting the Championship season in October is probably the best outcome for all that we could have hoped for.The costs for some of the smaller teams in the ision of starting earlier were simply too great.The issues and reservations were vast, perhaps not so much for the likes of Dundee and the now officially relegated Hearts, but definitely for part-time Alloa and Arbroath and newly-promoted Raith.In terms of adhering to all the coronavirus protocols it would have been a huge challenge but McPake and Co will still be left feeling slightly frustrated.They’ve already had three months out and now face another four before a ball is kicked in anger.He will be keen to get his side back in training to see where they’re at, what they need to do to strengthen and plan his assault on ashortened second season in the Dens Park hotseat.I’ve touched on it in this column before but players, particularly in the lower reaches of Scottish football, need peace of mind right now.Some teams, like Dundee, had extended contracts while a decision on Ann Budge’s reconstruction proposal and a date for when the lower leagues willwas made.Now we know a -team Championship is set to get under way in October, squads will slowly be assembled.It’s another small victory.I tried watching German football but theof the English Premier League tomorrowNo offence but Dortmund versus Mainz just isn’t the same as Man City against title: sean hamilton dundee united dunfermline tough talk kevin nisbet
story: It’s no surprise that Dunfermline chairman Ross McArthur is playing hardball over Kevin Nisbet.But “hardball” isn’t the operative word – it’s “playing”.The Pars chief came out swinging after Dundee United went public with their continued interest in his star striker this week.In a move that injected some much-needed knockabout fun into Scottish football after a stony-faced few months, he branded United boss Robbie Neilson’s decision to speak publicly about Nisbet “disrespectful”.Dunfermline fans would expect no less.However, McArthur also insisted Nisbet will not be sold for “a cheap price”.Saying that is one thing, but being able to guarantee it is another altogether.At a time when football clubs have been haemorrhaging cash – with Dunfermline feeling the pinch like everybody  – this transfer window is going to be shaped by disaster capitalism.Just last month, the Pars axed  players in a move designed, in their chairman’s words, to “protect the business”.It’s hardly surprisingclubs in somewhat ruder financial health, having clocked that decision, are scenting blood in the water.And it’s no shock whatsoever that United, having seen a sizable bid for Nisbet knocked back just six months ago, are amongst those circling.They aren’t alone.Hibs were also keen on Nisbet in January – and they haven’t gone away.Portsmouth have also had an eye on the Pars star, and should they firm up their interest, the Pars could well get a reasonable price for their main man.But even clubs of Portsmouth’s size aren’t going to drop huge transfer fees this summer.Ordinarily, Dunfermline would be wise to set their asking price above market value and hope it rises.But in a football landscape scorched by a months-long dearth of income, that tactic is far less likely to work.And, as every fan knows,a player decides he wants a move, he usually ends up getting it, evenhis club has to take a hit on price.The Pars’ chairman has been vocal in recent months about the dficulties his club have faced during the coronavirus shutdown.He deserves credit for his candidness on the topic.But this summer, it’s going to be a buyer’s market – and Dunfermline, despite the tough talk, look more like sellers.I’ve felt bad for Dundee all week.With excitement mounting about the Premiership’s , with top flight clubs ing to training, and with closed-doors football getting underway around Europe, the Dark Blues have been left on the outside looking in.In speaking to Dee gaffer, James McPake, this week, I got the feeling that frustration is mounting.He expressed it in a typically measured way – there was no ranting or raving.He acknowledged the situation in which he and his players find themselves is nowhere near as worthy of complaint as many other things that are happening in the wider world.But the truth is the lack of a start date for next season’s Championship has left Dundee # and their fellow second tier sides # in limbo.Without a target to work towards, McPake can’t properly plan for what will be a big campaign.Some other clubs might be okay with the situation.But Dundee are a side with ambitions # and, right now, they’re being held back.Fair play to United fans.Over  of them have shelled out for season tickets despite not knowing when they’ll set foot inside Tannadice.That shows the punters’ passion for and commitment to their club.At a time when finances are tighter than ever in football, it will also have provided a welcome cash boost at Tannadice.And I don’t think it will be long until fans see it being spent.I watched the Seville derby between Sevilla and Real Betis as La Liga ed on Thursday night.
