title: virtual-beltane-festival-begins-peebles
story: A VIRTUAL Beltane Festival is under way in Peebles.The physical event was cancelled due to coronavirus restrictions.But residents are nevertheless being urged to take part in a range of activities this week.In a video message posted on Facebook, festival chairman Paul Spence said: "We still wanted to ensure we marked the occasion in the best way that we can."Mr Spence called on residents to "turn the town red and white".He said: "Lets get the bunting up, lets celebrate our great festival and,you want, include some previous house decorations."He also invited people to update their social media profiles with red-and-white images and pictures of previous festivals."Lets get as many great memories on social media as possible," he said.More information on events being held this week can be found on the Beltane Facebook page, said Mr Spence.Activities include a quiz on June  and a couple of virtual discos.

title: face-masks-wear-one-properly-stop-glasses-steaming
story: A NEW law means that face coverings are now compulsory acrossEngland when using public transport.Some form of facial protection must be worn for commuters to be able to travel on public trains and buses as of today , with the law to be enforced by transport operators and British Transport police ldquo necessary.Travellers can be fined and refused travelthey do not comply with the law.Very young children, disabled people and those who have breathing dficulties are exempt from the rules, but all other public transport users must comply fromJune .At the time of publication - similar rules regarding face masks and public transport have not been implemented across Scotland, Walesand Northern Ireland.But which types of face coverings are acceptable, and how do you wear them properly How do I wear a face mask properly The UK Government has advised that scarves, or homemade cotton coverings, that cover the nose and mouth are fine to wear- so, too, arebought masks that are not the same as those used by the health service.Surgical masks should be kept for use by health professionals.Officials have said that people can make a face covering at home, but added it is key to ensure it covers your nose and mouth.Government guidancestates that a cloth face covering should cover your mouth and nose while allowing you to breathe comfortably. This can be as simple as a scarf or bandana that ties behind the head.Before putting it on, you should wash your hands or use hand sanitiser and do the same after removing it.Avoid touching your eyes, nose, or mouth at all times and store any used face coverings in a plastic bag until you have an opportunity to wash them.Do not touch the front of the face covering, or the part of the face covering that has been in contact with your mouth and nose.Once removed, make sure you clean any surfaces the face covering has touched and wash the covering regularly. The covering can be washed with other laundry, using your normal detergent.When wearing a face covering, take care to tuck away any loose ends.How do I stop my glasses from steaming up If you wear glasses, wearing a face mask at the same time can cause the lenses to steam up, making it dficult to see properly.But the common problem has an easy solution, thanks to advice from doctors in the medical journal Annals of the Royal College of Surgeons of England.To prevent the issue, doctors advise washing your glasses with soapy water before putting the mask on, and rinsing them under warm water.Then, gently dry off the lenses with a clean towel or cloth before putting them back on.Washing the lenses with soapy water leaves behind a ldquothin surfactant film that reduces misting on the lenses, meaning they now shouldnrsquot steam up when a face mask is worn.Should face coverings be worn where The current government advice states that face coverings should be worn in enclosed spaces, which includes some shops and public transport.At the moment, people are not being told to wear them outdoors, while exercising, or in schools or offices.Several airlines, including easyJet and Ryanair, have introduced a requirement for passengers to wear face masks on board.However, the government believes that face masks should be reserved for people who need them to protect against risks in their workplace, such as health and care workers.

title: borders-priest-moving-rome-new-job
story: A BORDERS priest has accepted a high-ranking job in Rome.Nick Welsh, , has been based in Galashiels for the past two years.But he will soon be flying out to Italy after being picked for the role of vice-rector at the Scots College, where aspiring Scottish priests receive their training.Father Nick, originally from Stirling, told the Border he had ldquomixed emotions when he heard the news.He said: ldquoIrsquom quite excited, but Irsquoll have a bit of a heavy heart when I leave ndash I was just getting used to the Borders.Since , Father Nick has been administrator of the Parish of Our Lady  St Andrew, which has churches in Galashiels, Melrose and Selkirk.He said: ldquoI was really warmly welcomed here. Irsquom a bit of a city boy, but I was very much welcomed into a place I was very unfamiliar with.Asked what his favourite parts of the job have been, he highlighted working with local children, saying: ldquoIt was a really great thing to be involved with the schools here.His routine has seen him leading services in Galashiels , Melroseand Selkirk .But he has also visited the Borders General Hospital and people who are unable to leave home due to illness.Last week, however, he received a surprise phone call saying he had been selected for the Scots College job.ldquoI was a student there from -, so itrsquos a very familiar place but it was quite a surprise to me to be asked to go back, Father Nick said.ldquoIrsquove only been here for two years and I thought I would be here for a bit longer.ldquoOften you would be in a place for  years before you move on.Father Nick was happy to accept the new post, though, having enjoyed living in the Italian capital previously.ldquoI loved living in Rome so Irsquom quite excited about moving back, he said.ldquoI love being a priest and helping others to become a priest will be something Irsquoll be quite energised by.Father Nick, who intends to fly out in August, will be second-in-command and will take care of the administration of the college.He says he will also teach priests ldquohow to preach and give guidance on ldquopractical aspects of the job.The Scots College currently boasts three Borderers in its ranks, according to Father Nick ndash including former disc jockey Bobby Taylor from Galashiels.Josh Moir is also from Galashiels, while Martin Eckersley is from Jedburgh.

title: easyjet-restarts-flights-full-list-destinations-can-fly
story: Easyjet has restarted a small number of its flightsto a limited amountof destinations withstricter cleaning and safety measures for staff and passengers.Heres a round-up ofeverything you need to know.When did Easyjet restart flights Easyjet relaunched its flights from  airports across Europe for the first time on Monday, June , since they were halted at the end of March due to the coronavirus pandemic.The first flight from the UK took off on Monday morning from London Gatwick at am for Glasgow, which was the same flight path the airline first took when it launched in November .What destinations is Easyjet flying to Easyjet will be offering a reduced roster of destinations available for passengers - the plan is to be able to fly  per cent of its normal , routes in July, and  per cent in August.While there will be fewer flights on offer, travellers will have their pick of flights to domestic, city and beach destinations.These are all the destinations available from the Easyjet summer  flying programme:AlbaniaAustriaBelgiumBulgariaCroatiaCyprusCzech RepublicDenmarkEgyptEstoniaFranceGermanyGibraltarGreeceHungaryIcelandIsraelItalyKosovoMontenegroMoroccoNetherlandsPolandPortugalSerbiaSloveniaSpainSwedenSwitzerlandTurkeyCities around the UKThe airline confirmed that flights will resume from airports across the UK, including:London GatwickBristolBirminghamLiverpoolNewcastleEdinburghGlasgowInvernessBelfastWhat are the increased safety measures for staff and passengers Easyjet has introduced extra safety measures in order to keep staff and passengers safe during their flights.Additional cleaning and disinfection procedures for aircraft cabins will be in place, with every aircraft subject to a daily disinfection process.All passengers and crew will be required to wear masks at all times. The airline has also teamed up with a superhero illustrator to create comic book-inspired face masks for children.Artist Will Sliney is best known for his work on Marvel comics, like Spiderman and Star Wars.Aircrafts will be fully equipped with sanitary equipment - including masks, gloves and hand sanitiser -which will be available to customers and crew throughout the flight, where required.The aircraft are also fitted with ldquostate of the art filtration technology which ldquofilters . per cent of airborne contaminants in the cabin, including virus and bacteria, according to a statement from Easyjet.

title: free-school-meals-extended-scotland-summer---know

not to extend their scheme in England - with Manchester United footballer Marcus Rashford pleading for a U-turn.Speaking at her daily briefing in Edinburgh today, in which she revealed a further five available to around , children across Scotland, either within local authority premises which are still open or through direct cash payments, supermarket vouchers or the direct supply of meals."I can confirm that this provision will be extended throughout the summer holiday period, we know families are under considerable financial pressures and free school meals are a help to many."But they are also important to the health and wellbeing of young children.ldquoWe will provide pound. million in funding to local authorities to enable the continuation of free school meals during the period from the end of June to the start of the new term in August.The First Minister said the funding would be allocated ldquoin a way that allows councils, as many of them do, to co-ordinate school meal or who face other barriers to accessing food.Ms Sturgeon also told the briefing that she ldquoexpected to be able to move into the second phase of the Scottish route map out of lockdown on Thursday, title: runner-ticking-off-borders-towns---seen-yet
story: A GALASHIELS man is running through a dozen towns for a fundraiser in memory of his late sister.Craig Lowrie, , challenged himself to complete km in each town during the common riding season.Mr Lowrie is dedicating his efforts to his late sister Donna Cameron, who died in a car crash on June , .The keen amateur footballer said: "The money that I raise in my sisters memory will be split between common riding committees across the Borders, with donors choosing which towns festival their money will go towards."Mr Lowriersquos son was the Braw Lad in Galashiels last year ndash and now Mr Lowrie is running through each town that Robbie visited."My sister loved the common riding season, and was so proud and excited for Robbie ahead of the big day last year, said Mr Lowrie."Sadly, she died just a few weeks before and didnrsquot get the chance to watch her nephew carry out his duties."Donations will help common riding committees make up for not being able to hold fundraisers due to the coronavirus pandemic, says Mr Lowrie.However,donors prefer, they can ask for their money to go to the childrens ward at the Borders General Hospitalndash another cause close to Mr Lowriersquos heart.He said: "The staff in ward  were fantastic with my daughter Jorga, who had a number of blood transfusions during the first six years of her le, due to having a rare blood disorder."Thankfully, she is well on the road to recovery, and wersquore very grateful to all the staff in the ward. Its great to be able to give something back."Mr Lowrie, who plays football for Selkirk Victoria AFC, has already gone the distance in Hawick, Selkirk and Melrose ndash and will arrive in Peebles tomorrow .His online GoFundMe campaign has proved a success over the last few weeks.A total of pound, has been donated by  people [as at .am, June ], and the fundraiser has been shared  times on social media."The majority of money so far has been donated to either ward  at the BGH or the Braw Ladsrsquo Gathering committee of Galashiels," said Mr Lowrie."Im keen to raise as much awareness as possible for the cause so that other towns can benefit too."Other towns on the list are Jedburgh, Duns, Innerleithen, Kelso, Musselburgh, Lauder and Coldstream.And on June , Mr Lowrie will run km in Galashiels, one year after Robbie led proceedings.He said: "Hopefully, Ill be able to get some sort of [socially distanced] crowd to cheer me on as Im going up Scott Street, where the horses would normally go."Im trying to convince Robbie to join me for a part of it, but hes not agreed to anything yet."Although Innerleithen does not have a common riding, they do have a games week in July.And as Donna lived much of her le there, Mr Lowrie thought it would be fitting for the towns festival to be able to benefit.He said: "Ive been blown away with peoples generosity."Id like to say a big thank you as well to local companies ndash including Tesco in Galashiels, who donated blister packs, water and Haribos."The blister packs will definitely be needed, as Ive been running in the same pair of shoes for months and one of the toes has worn away!Details of the fundraiser can be found here.

title: selkirk-community-council-holds-first-online-meeting
story: SELKIRK Community Council hosted its first online annual general meetingyesterday evening .During the meeting, all current members remained in their posts, with council chairman Alistair Pattullo the first to be retained.Reflecting on the coronavirus outbreak, Mr Pattullo told members: "Since our last meeting, our lives have changed."He went on to praise the work of the Selkirk Response Team, which treasurer Judith Thompson reported had received a total of pound, over the previous year.Mr Pattullo particularly commended the efforts of Graham Easton for helping residents during the virus crisis.He added: "Im sure this community council will continue to do the best for the community."After confirming appointments to community council roles, items of regular business were raised.Topics included:Concerns over water continuing to run off Forest Mill at Dunsdale RoadDavid Deacons suggestion that a local high school pupil should join the committeePraise for Selkirks resilience during the pandemic ndash Caroline Cochrane described the creation of face masks as "a great bit of community spirit"Ms Cochrane also outlined plans for Selkirk Farmers Market, noting local stall holders hopes that the event wouldbefore August.Ms Cochrane said there is a "lot of work to be done", adding that only food stalls will feature when the market s.For updates on future meetings, and to access the community councils AGM  minutes ndash when available ndash visit: www.selkirkcommunitycouncil

title: record-low-alcohol-sales-scotland-last-year
story: ALCOHOL sales in Scotland remain at their lowest level on record for a second year, a study has found.A total of . litres of alcohol was sold per adult last year, the equivalent of  units per person each week.The annual Monitoring and Evaluating Scotlands Alcohol Strategyreport found sales were at the same level as , maintaining the lowest level since recording began in .Minimum unit pricing came into force on May ,  and requires all licensed premises in Scotland to set a floor price of p per unit of alcohol.The average price of alcohol sold in Scottish supermarkets and off-licences rose to  pence per unitin , up from ppu in .Meanwhile, the volume of pure alcohol sold in Scotland was  per cent higher than in England and Wales, representing the smallest dference since .Alcohol-specic death rates are consistently higher in Scotland than south of the border.The rates are nearly twice as high for men and  per cent higher for women.The most recent figures for  show , people died in Scotland due to a cause wholly attributable to alcohol.Deaths in the  per cent most deprived areas were more than four times higher than in the  per cent least deprived areas.Public Health Scotland, the agency that has taken over responsibility for MESAS, said too many people were exceeding the guidelines on alcohol despite the encouraging trends.Lucie Giles, public health intelligence principal, said: "Population level alcohol consumption in Scotland has remained at the level the MESAS programme reported last year."Based on alcohol sales, average alcohol consumption in  is estimated at . litres of pure alcohol per adult in Scotland."This is the lowest we have seen in the available data and maintains the smallest dference between Scotland and England  Wales since the early s."Despite these encouraging trends, the most recent survey data shows that nearly a quarter of adults exceeded the revised low-risk weekly drinking guidelines, and that drinkers in the lowest income group are likely to consume more."She added: "An average of  people per week are still dying as a result of their alcohol consumption and again this is not spread evenly throughout the population ndash those in the most deprived areas are more likely to be hospitalised or die because of an alcohol-related cause."Like all harm caused by alcohol, this is preventable."Public Health Scotland will continue to monitor and evaluate Scotlands alcohol strategy, so we can continue to gauge progress and understand what works to reduce the harm alcohol causes."

title: borders-couple-lot-celebrate-week

title: borders-hotel-chief-ditch-2m-rule-distancing
story: A HOTEL chief is calling for the two-metre social-distancing rule to be dropped.Stobo Castle chairman Stephen Winyard believes thousands of hospitality workers will be made redundant across the UKthe guidance continues unchanged.Mr Winyard, , said: ldquoThe impact on the tourism sector will be horrendous in terms of jobs lost.Instead of the two-metre recommendation, Mr Winyard would like to see a one-metre rule introduced.Tweeddale MP David Mundell has sympathised with the suggestion, agreeing that the guidance should be reviewed.Mr Winyard, a director of the luxury Peeblesshire hotel, believes the example set by some other countries should be followed.He points to the one-metre rule in France, as well as Germanyrsquos .-metre recommendation."The World Health Organisationsays one metre is safe, said Mr Winyard. ldquoWeve gone to the most extreme [distancing measures] in the world."He added: ldquoA decision to halve social distancing will help to kickstart this sectorrsquos recovery, save countless jobs and in following the WHOrsquos guidance on this subject, still allow our respective governments to discharge their sacred duty of safeguarding the publicrsquos health.Asked to comment on Mr Winyardrsquos plea, Mr Mundell, of the Conservatives, said: "There appears to be a weight of evidence from a number of countries and organisations that one-metre distancing can strike a reasonable balance between safeguarding health and providing a practical way of working."Hospitality and tourism are amongst the most important employers in Tweeddale ndash and right across my constituency ndash and many jobs and businesses depend on workable safe solutions being established as soon as possible."It is vital that the Scottish Government reviews the two-metre rule to help ensure the sector is best placed to come out of lockdown providing a safe and appealing environment for both customers and staff."Meanwhile, Tweeddale MSP Christine Grahame told the Peeblesshire Newsthat she appreciates the dficulties posed by the two-metre rule, but she added that it exists for peoplersquos safety.The SNP member said: ldquoThe virus has not gone away and the margins for ensuring the virus does not take off again remain tight.ldquoThe scientic advice has not changed and that is why the two-metre rule is in place, to protect everyone.ldquoI understand and sympathise greatly with the limitations this rule puts on many businesses but the priority must still be to protect everyonersquos health.ldquoHowever, along with all the other measures, the two-metre rule is under constant review and any relaxation will happenand when it is deemed safe to do so.ldquoWe know the restrictions cause harms of their own, and they will not be kept in place for a moment longer than is necessary.Mr Winyard said he views the Scottish Governmentrsquos approach as ldquovery cautious.But he added that he believes any reduction in social distancing would have to take into account Scotlands lsquoR ratersquo and the effectiveness of the track and trace programme.

title: phase-2-13-new-changes-scotlands-lockdown-restrictions-eased
story: NICOLA Sturgeon has today announced a further easing of lockdown measures in Scotland.Throughout the last week, the First Minister had indicated her optimism at moving the country into Phase  of the four-phased route map out of lockdown restrictions.The decision was made at the three-weekly formal review of the measures, following a further suppression of the coronavirus in Scotland ndash with the NRS revealing yesterday the number of virus-related deaths fell for the seventh week in a row.But what does Phase  actually mean for you From seeing family and friends to outdoor shopping, here are the biggest changes from the latest easing of lockdown.From June Shielding peopleFrom today, people who are shielding can go outdoors for exercise.Shielding people can also take part in non-contact outdoor activity, such as golf, from tomorrow.From tomorrow, people who are shielding can also meet people from one other household.From Friday, June Seeing friends and familyThe First Minister today revealed people can enter other households to use the toilet - but should continue meeting outdoors.You will also be able to meet with larger groups including family and friends outside - with the maximum of two extra households and eightpeople.This is in addition to the measures from Phase , which included sunbathing sitting outdoors, and visiting other households outdoors and in gardens.Extended householdFrom tomorrow, people who live alone or with children under  can have a bubble with one other household - you can visit indoors and stay overnight.This has to be with this household only.TransportPublic transport can increase their capacity but will remain signicantly limited to allow for physical distancing.Face masks will be mandatory on all public transport.The First Minister says the five-mile limit for leisure and recreational purposes will remain for now - "remain as close as possible to local area" until Phase .There is no five-mile limit for visiting family and friends.From Monday, June DentistsAll dental practices can reopen to see patients with urgent care needs from Phase  ndash meanwhile procedures which generate aerosols will remain at emergency dental hubs.SportsThe guidance also says the resumption of professional sport, in line with public health advice, is allowed.As with the previous Phase, unrestricted outdoors exercise is permitted, so long as you adhere to distancing measures. Non-contact sports like golf, hiking, fishing etc remain allowed.However, gyms will not be able to reopen until Phase .WorshipThe route map also says places of worship will be able to reopen for private prayer - but not for extended groups until Phase .,params: .pushFrom Monday, June ShoppingOutdoor markets can also reopen, provided there can be controls on the number of people within the market and distancing is kept.The First Minister also outlined plans fornon-essential retail units to reopen form June - but these will have to have outside entrances. Therefore shopping centres cannot reopen.Drive-thrus and garden centres were already permitted to reopen under the previous easing of measures.SportsSports courts and playgrounds are now permitted to reopen across Scotland.WorkingWorking from home remains the default position.But the guidance says non-essential indoor, non-office based workplaces can reopen - including factories, warehouses, lab and research facilities.The construction sector can also implement further stages of a phased .There can also be a relaxation of restriction on housing moves.MarriagesUnder Phase , marriages and civil partnerships can take place in Scotland with the number of attendees kept to a minimal.Moving houseRelaxation on restrictions on housing moves.EducationCollege and university staff canto make essential preparations for restart in Phase .These institutionswill not until Phase , with schools set toacross Scotland from August .

title: clarks-closes-shoe-shop-galashiels
story: CLARKS has closed its Galashiels shoe shop which employs nine staff.The company has decided not to renew the lease at the Gala Water site.A spokesperson says the closure is ldquoin no way related to the coronavirus pandemic.A statement reads: "At Clarks, we continually review all of our stores to ensure that they are the right size and located in the right areas in order to provide the best possible offering and environment to our customers."After careful consideration, we have decided to no longer trade at Galashiels."Decisions have yet to be made about workersrsquo futures, the company says, with employees currently engaged in talks.The spokesperson said  stores are closing across the UK, including four in Scotland.

title: shielding-people-scotland-can-cannot-phase-2
story: THE First Minister yesterday outlined plans to provide a ldquoreal improvement to the quality of le of those shielding in Scotland.As part of measures being eased as the country moved into Phase  of lockdown, Nicola Sturgeon revealed those people shielding would be among those to experience change immediately.There are around , people in the shielding group,which includes organ transplant recipients, those on active chemotherapy, those with severe lung disease, those with certain metabolic diseases, the signicantly immunosuppressed and pregnant women with underlying heart problems.They also included anyone primary care physicians deemed vulnerable.At the start of the pandemic they were all sent a letter telling them to stay indoors and take extra precautions until June .Last week, Nicola Sturgeon extended that, telling them that they would need to shield until the end of July.So what has changed for people shielding in Scotland Here we outline what you can and cannot do now we have moved into Phase .Irsquom in a shielding household, what CAN I do now Confirming her pledge last week, the First Minister revealed that anyone who is shielding , can nowgo outdoors for exercise ndash whether it be a walk, a wheel or cycle.But the First Minister added an extra easing. From today ndash Friday, June  ndash shielding people can also take part in non-contact outdoor activities.This includes things likegolf, fishingand hillwalking.Ms Sturgeon also revealed that those shielding can meet outdoors with people from one other household ndash however these are to be in groups of no more than eight.When you do go outside, you are urged to choose times and areas that are quiet ndash and wash your hands thoroughly as soon as you get back home.What can I still NOT do The First Minister urged people who are shielding to ldquocontinue to be extremely cautious ndash remaining at least  metres away from other people at all times, ldquoevenyou live with the person yoursquore out with.Unlike the general public, you cannot go inside someone rsquos house, or allow someone from another household to go inside yours ndash even to just use the toilet.What has the reaction been Brian Sloan, chief executive of Age Scotland, described the announcement as a ldquolight at the end of the tunnel for older people.He said: ldquoThe easing of lockdown for hundreds of thousands of older people living alone will come as a huge relief.ldquoSo many older people have endured lockdown without any face to face contact with family or friends for three months now, and it has been extremely dficult for them.ldquoFor the half a million over-s in Scotland who donrsquot use the internet, there hasnrsquot even been the option of video calls with loved ones. They have had to rely on the phone for conversation.ldquoThe result of such prolonged isolation is that loneliness levels are through the roof and having a profound impact on the mental and physical health of older people.He added: ldquoTodayrsquos announcement is a small step towards normality, and must of course be done in compliance with safety guidelines, but at last there is light at the end of the tunnel for our older people who have felt very cut off from society during this pandemic.ldquoThey can now look forward to seeing family and friends and when it is safe to do so, being part of their communities again.

title: covid-alert-level-system-changes-mean
story: THE UKrsquos chief medical officers have agreed to downgrade the coronavirus alert level from four to three following a "steadyand continuing"decrease in cases in all four nations.Localised outbreaks of COVID- are still "likely"to occur, the advisers warned - and the virus remains in general circulation.But the downgrading ndash recommended by the Joint Biosecurity Centrendash means transmission of coronavirus is no longer considered to be ldquohigh or rising exponentially.Englandrsquos Professor Chris Whitty, Northern Irelandrsquos Dr Michael McBride, Scotlandrsquos Dr Gregor Smith and Walesrsquo Dr Chris Jones agreed with the JBCrsquos recommendation.But what is the alert system and how does it work Heres what you need to know.What is the alert system The Covid Alert Levels system was announced by Prime Minister Boris Johnson in his televised address to the nation on May .The system is similar to that used to establish the terrorist threat and will be run by a new Joint Biosecurity Centre.It has five tiers from level one to five based on the spread of COVID- through the UK.The Covid- alert level system. Picture credit: PA GraphicsHow does it work Mr Johnson said that the UKs current alert level will be determined primarily by the virusrsquo reproduction rate ndash the average number of people that will contract coronavirus from an infected person ndash and the number of coronavirus cases.The level will then inform the government what measures are needed to combat the spread of the virus, with higher levels requiring stricter controls.What are the dferent levels When the scheme was launched the country was at level four which means a ldquoCOVID- epidemic is in general circulation, transmission is high or rising exponentially.The system says that current social distancing measures and restrictions should remain in place.Level five is when transmission is high or rising but also when there was a risk of healthcare services being overwhelmed and will require an increase in social distancing measures.Level one means there COVID- is no longer known to be in the UK and the only action should be ldquoroutine international monitoring.Level three is when the epidemic is in general circulation and gradual easing of restrictions can take place, while level two is when the number of cases and transmission is low and ldquono or minimal restrictions are required.But under level two there will be enhanced testing, tracing, monitoring and screening.Who monitors and sets the level Mr Johnson said he was establishing a new Joint Biosecurity Centre to run the alert system.Cabinet Office documents said the centre will provide real-time analysis and assessment of COVID- outbreaks at a community level to enable rapid action to stop spikes in infection.It will also advise on specic actions which can be taken to manage rising numbers of infections, such as closing schools or businesses.The centre will also inform the chief medical officers of a change in the COVID- Alert level who will then advise ministers.

story: Boris Johnsonrsquos pound billion plan to help pupils catch up with learning has come under fire from education leaders, as the UKrsquos chief medical officers have agreed to downgrade the title: wales-travel-restrictions-end-tourism-return-july-says-drakeford
story: Wales plans to end its five-mile restriction on travel next month and allow holidaymakers toa week later, the First Minister has said.Mark Drakeford said tourism businesses have three weeks to prepare for the potential changes, which will allow the use of self-contained accommodation such as caravans and cottages.On Friday, Mr Drakeford said the further headroom to lt restrictions has been created by the efforts of the public to bring coronavirus under control in Wales, where the R number shows Covid- is receding at a faster rate than in England.He told BBC Radio Wales ahead of Fridayrsquos press conference that he wanted people to do ldquoone last lap of the ldquostay local instruction, which restricts travel to five miles, ahead of scrapping it on July .ldquoThe lsquostay localrsquo restrictions will end provided that the virus is still where we need it to be, he said.ldquoOnce the lsquostay localrsquo restriction is over, itrsquos over for all purposes and all distances.vw,vw,px, px"On reopening the tourism industry, Mr Drakeford said: ldquoI will be saying to the visitor economy in Wales that they should use the coming three weeks to prepare to reopen self-contained accommodation in Wales during the month of July.ldquolsquoSelf-containedrsquo is very important because coronavirus spreads where people come together and where they share facilities.ldquoSo,you have a static caravan thatrsquos got its own kitchen and its own bathroom,yoursquore renting a cottage,yoursquore going to a hotel that has turned itself into self-contained accommodation, therersquoll be a clear signal from me today that you should use the next three weeks to get everything in place.The First Minister will formally announce what he calls the most ldquocomprehensive package of measures announced yet for Wales at the Welsh Governmentrsquos press briefing on Friday afternoon.As well as allowing all non-essential retail businesses to reopen from Monday, it is also expected to include allowing private prayer in places of worship, enabling house viewings to take place in empty properties, and house moves where a sale has already been agreed, and lting restrictions on outdoor non-contact inidual sports like tennis..push,i[r].l*new Dateas,ms[]a.asynca.srcgmgagagagagagagagagagaga, title: Wales travel restrictions to end and tourism toin title: north-berwick-teen-signs-edinburgh-rugby
story: Ben Muncaster, from North Berwick, was one of three signings completed by the capital side last Friday.The back-row moves from Leicester Tigers, where he spent four years as part of the Premiership sidersquos academy.The -year-old said: ldquoIrsquom extremely excited to be joining this club.ldquoI grew up in North Berwick and have always loved Edinburgh as a city, so to be joining the professional rugby team is a dream come true.And he added: ldquoEdinburgh are obviously a very strong team with a great culture.ldquoThey have some exceptional players that I have looked up to for many years.ldquoIrsquoll hopefully try and learn from them as much as I can, certainly in the back row.ldquoIt is such an honour to have been given an opportunity like this, I am very grateful for it, and I want to make the absolute most of it.The teenager, who attended Loretto School, Musselburgh, joins Edinburgh alongside fellow Scotland age-grade players Nathan Chamberlain, who moves from Bristol Bears, and Dan Gamble, who has signed from Heriotrsquos Rugby.Richard Cockerill, head coach at Edinburgh Rugby, was pleased to sign the trio.He said: ldquoItrsquos hugely important that we continue to develop and nurture young Scottish talent, so itrsquos brilliant that wersquove been able to sign three very impressive age-grade players.ldquoBen has come through the ranks at Leicester and has consistently improved his game year after year.ldquoHe will only get better being involved and training with a talented back-row group here at Edinburgh.Muncaster has previously represented Scotland during the under-s Six Nations.Previously speaking to the Leicester Tigers website, he said: ldquoI lived near my local club when I was a kid and so itrsquos no surprise I started playing when I was about four or five.ldquoMy dad enjoys watching but never really played ndash I joined my local rugby club and loved every minute of it.

title: county-rugby-club-given-1-000-boost
story: Dunbar RFC has been given the four-figure sum by Persimmon Homes Building Futures scheme.The initiative will see poundmillion given away across Britain to regional charities, groups, sports clubs and schools to improve local facilities and the delivery of vital community projects for people aged under .Dunbar Rugby Football Club is the first recipient of the recently launched initiative and supports more than  people under the age of .The club works closely with primary and secondary schools to encourage young people to play rugby in a safe and enjoyable environment.The club plan to use the funds to replace fencing that surrounds the main pitch at Hallhill Sports Centre.Building Futures aims to support community groups working with under-s across three categories ndash education and arts, health and sport.In addition to hundreds of local donations of pound,,  initiatives will go on to compete for top prizes of pound, through a national online public vote.Laura Still, sales and marketing director for Persimmon Homes East Scotland, said: ldquoWe are proud to support Dunbar Rugby Football Club, who offer a valuable opportunity for young people to develop new skills and boost confidence.ldquoWith so many chances to win vital funding for their projects, we urge charities, schools and sports clubs to apply online before May .

title: scottish-open-take-place-renaissance-club-october
story: The impact of the coronavirus saw the Aberdeen Standard Investments Scottish Open postponed last month.However, the European Tour has now confirmed that the tournament, which will be played at The Renaissance Club, near Archerfield, will take place from October -.Keith Pelley, European Tour Chief Executive, said: ldquoSince the suspension of our  season in early March, we have taken a measured approach in reassessing our schedule, informed every step of the way by our medical advisers and government guidance.ldquoWe have consistently said that safety is our absolute priority and that is why today we are announcing our resumption in two monthsrsquo time supported by a comprehensive health strategy which has been led by our medical team.ldquoWithout question we have had to think dferently about the remainder of our  season which is reflected in todayrsquos announcement.ldquoAs golfrsquos global Tour, ersity is ordinarily one of our biggest strengths, but in this instance it has become one of our biggest challenges.ldquoInitially, therefore, based on the expert guidance we received, playing in clusters, in one territory, is the best option in terms of testing, travel and accommodation.It is the second year in a row that the competition has been played at the East Lothian course.Last yearrsquos event was won by Bernd Wiesberger after a play-off with Benjamin Hebert.Among those hoping to line up at the tournament is North Berwicks Grant Forrest.The -year-old, who finished tied for rd at least years event, said: "It is great it is going ahead."Obviously, so much uncertainty in the last few months and the guys on the European Tour have been working really hard to put something together for us."I am glad they have got it on the schedule and I hope the weather is alright in October ndash who knows what it could be like "There was a point where I thought it would almost be a year off, which would have been a real shame."They have done really well to give us so many events already and with the hope they could add a few more."Councillor John McMillan, East Lothian Councilrsquos spokesman for economic development and tourism, was pleased to hear the event had been rescheduled.He said: ldquoI very much look forward to welcoming world class golfers back to East Lothian for this fantastic tournament."We will of course work closely with the European Tour and in accordance with guidance on the detail of how the tournament can be run safely."It is an encouraging development and signals that Scotlandrsquos Golf Coast will be back open for business this year albeit with some restrictions still in place.Councillor Jeremy Findlay, who represents the North Berwick Coastal ward, was similarly pleased to see the event rescheduled but stressed it remained to be seen how the tournament would look in terms of a crowd.He said: "I think it is great news not only for Scottish golf itself but for tourism in general."Hopefully, by then, we will be able to have crowds as well but I am really not sure what the rules on that are going to be yet ndash whether it is crowds or played behind closed doors, it would be a bit oddit was behind closed doors."In general, we will have to wait and see what the rules are about crowds."That is what produces the benefit in the short-term to the local economy."Mr Findlay highlighted that the tourism sector had taken "a huge hit" during the coronavirus crisis and many businesses would have to survive until next year before tourism started to resume in the traditional way.Currently, the Aberdeen Standard Investments Ladies Scottish Open is pencilled in for August - at the same venue.Last yearrsquos event was won by Mi Jung Hur.

title: schoolchildren-share-self-help-guides-coping-lockdown
story: They were tasked with producing, from home, advice on how to relax, and how to deal with boredom and being at home for such a long time.The youngsters in P also shared fun and interesting activities theyrsquod enjoyed during the lockdown.Teacher Stefan Thomson said: ldquoThis was part of their weekly learning grid, which contains learning tasks from a iety of dferent curricular areas.ldquoIrsquove been absolutely astounded with the resilience pupils have shown during this time.He added: ldquoThis task was intended to be a fun way to share coping strategies among pupils.ldquoHowever, after reading their amazing suggestions I realised how useful these could be for everyone finding it hard to cope.The children suggested activities such as yoga and meditation, as well as stressing the need for healthy eating.

title: musselburgh-marlins-become-first-east-lothian-club-achieve-top-swim-benchmark
story: Already proud holders of a SwiMark certicate, received in , they have now been awarded SwiMark Plus in Scottish Swimmingrsquos accreditation scheme which provides a nationally recognised standard for clubs and swim schools.Head coach Danny Kirkham said: ldquoMusselburgh Amateur Swimming Clubis delighted to have been awarded Scottish Swimmingrsquos highest accreditation, SwiMark Plus.ldquoThis means that Scottish Swimming recognises MASC as a quality programme which is swimmer centred and strives to ensure we provide the best environment possible for our swimmers to reach their full potential.ldquoThis award shows MASC are leading the way in setting new standards for swimming in the community. Through the work undertaken, a development plan which spans the whole club will ensure we keep progressing and moving forward to ensure MASC remains strong and sustainable long into the future.The club has come a long way since its origins in , when swimmers used to hone their skills in the local harbour. The pool at Loretto School was used over the years before the club moved to Musselburgh Sports Centre after it opened in .A year ago, MASCrsquos management committee and coaches held a planning meeting with Scottish Swimming to establish the steps required to be completed in order to achieve SwiMark Plus.A small voluntary project group embarked on reviewing, revising and signing off the extensive SwiMark criteria before engaging in consultative activities across the club, implementing revised and new policies and procedures, analysing data and producing a four year development and action plan.Club president and project manager Gill Downie said: ldquoMany thanks to the small project team heavily involved in delivering this huge feat through endless hours of blood, sweat and tears. It really is a remarkable achievement during the transitional year following chairman Jack Calderrsquos death ndash illustrating MASCrsquos resilience, drive and passion to be recognised as a trusted leader within aquatics sport by offering exceptional all-encompassing swimming development programmes, coaching education tuition and volunteer training within the community. In addition, effective club management and robust financial review systems will ensure MASC is a viable family-friendly resource within East Lothian well into the future.Alan Reed, Scottish Swimmingrsquos regional swimming development manger , added: ldquoWith the committee and other members working hard to gain this award, they have shown that they are a really strong and sustainable club.ldquoA crucial part of the accreditation is the formation of a development plan ndash this ensures that the club is making consistent progress and looks towards the future.ldquoThe club has excellent structures that have been put in place through the process and this has been demonstrated by all the engagement and activity the club has continued through this recent period of change. It has been a pleasure working with the club and helping support them to gain their SwiMark Plus accreditation.The top benchmark is also held by East Lothian Swim Team which provides a performance training environment for countyrsquos top talent. The best swimmers from Musselburgh, Tranent and Haddington Amateur Swimming Clubs train together as a single composite team to achieve success at East District, Scottish National, British and International levels.

title: schoolgirl-draws-picture-thank-keyworker-parents
story: Lucy Malcolm, nine, lives near Pinkie Primary School with mum Dianne, who works in the maternity department at the Royal Infirmary of Edinburgh dad Keith, who works for Royal Mail -year-old brother James, an apprentice electrician and -year-old brother Craig, a pupil at Musselburgh Grammar School.Lucy, a primary four pupil at Campie Primary School, used chalk to draw the image without any help.Her gran Ann Malcolm, who lives on the townrsquos Riverside Gardens and is a former headteacher of Windygoul and Saltoun Primary Schools, said: ldquoItrsquos quite amazing.ldquoHer parents were taken aback and really appreciated it.ldquoSome of the neighbours also went over to have a look at it.ldquoThatrsquos what itrsquos all about, though, thanking these key workers and celebrating them.Ann said that the family have been coping well with lockdown, with Lucyrsquos brothers James and Craig helping to look after Lucy while their parents were at work.She added that she was looking forward to reuniting with the family and her grandchildren for a socially distanced chat.

title: gala
story: Gala Queen Neve Campbell and Gala King Roby Gray, accompanied by piper Matt Sinclair, will walk round the village, waving their flags while observing Covid- pandemic social distancing rules.They will start at the local primary school at pm and cover most of Whitecraig.Local residents are being asked to stand safely at their gates to cheer on the royal party and mark the gala which has been cancelled this year due to the coronavirus crisis.They are also being urged to put up flags at their houses.

title: supermarket-supports-charity-meals
story: Scotmid Co-operative is backing the Pennypit Trust to provide food and essentials to those in need of support in Prestonpans.The Pennypit Trust improves health and wellbeing through sport, community development, nutrition, family engagement and volunteer development.During the Covid- pandemic, the trust has provided about , meals per week to Prestonpans families, the elderly and adults who are struggling.Scotmid has provided food vouchers to assist with ingredients for nutritious meals, as well as to donate to households who are struggling to buy fresh items.Kirsty Connell, Scotmid membership and community manager for the east of Scotland, said: ldquoWe are honoured to support the trust on its mission and provide help to those in need at this dficult time.The Pennypit Trust is predominantly relying on food donations to make up nutritious cooked meals, recipe bags and a basic essentials bag.Due to the high number of people who need support, stock of essential items has been in high demand and the trust is still receiving new referrals for people who need their help.Lorna Bellany, from the Pennypit Trust, was delighted with the donation.She said: ldquoWe have been overwhelmed by the kindness and generous donations we have received during this dficult time.ldquoThese vouchers from Scotmid will go a long way in helping us support families in the Prestonpans community.

title: plans-lodged-outdoor-adventure-playground-dogs
story: Dog activity parks and sensory gardens could be created as part of the proposals for Spilmersford Mains Farm, to the east of the village.A -acre section of land, north of the A, could be transformed specially for manrsquos best friend.Business documents are included in the planning application, which is being weighed up by East Lothian Councilrsquos planning department.It reads: ldquoAfter y research in the dog industrywe have assessed this to be a viable business in this location.ldquoWhat we want to do is provide a quality product in a good location that we think addresses a need that isnrsquot currently well served locally.ldquoOur customers will be a mixture of professional dog walkers and dog trainers using the adventure fields for both exercise and training with their client base. We also expect to welcome the dog-owning general public who are seeking a private and secure space to let their dog off the lead whilst also benefiting from an enriching experience within the sensory and agility zones in each field.ldquoAfter opening, we envisage eventually moving to a membership based access system and have hopefully successfully built a community of like-minded users.ldquoAll owners and dogs will be met for a compulsory induction session, where certicates of vaccinationswill be required and recorded with reminders sent out when they expire.Gordon Hood, of The Hood Partnership, is behind the plans, which will offer a range of services.The proposals outline being able to privately hire one of the three adventure fields, with each session lasting  minutes.Socialisation sessions would also take place at the weekend initially and are aimed at owners looking to socialise their dogs off the lead, as well as the possibility of dog training sessions.The plans state: ldquoWill be staffed initially by Gordon Hoodwith the potential for further employment opportunities further down the line depending on the business growth.ldquoGordon has undergone training at Safe Pawswith Shirley MacMillan who has been in the dog industry since  and is widely respected as a leading dog trainer and government advisor on best working practises in the industry.Expert advice has also been taken in terms of the design of any adventure park.The document notes: ldquoAfter much research in this area we have settled on a similar design in each field with dog agility equipment prevalent to allow dogs to improve their sense of balance and improve their strength and fitness.ldquoEffectively designed much like a childrenrsquos adventure playground, the parks are designed to stimulate the dogs mentally and physically.ldquoThe sensory lsquosnfrsquo gardens are packed full of natural smells and textures that help reduce a dogrsquos stress and anxiety.ldquoThey will be enclosed within a wooden fence akin to the example below and feature a field shelter and picnic table for customers to relax and enjoy their surroundings while their dog plays.ldquoThe agility zone is full of balancing equipment and a range of s to allow dogs to climb, explore and use up some of their stored up energy.

title: valet-cleans-paramedics-cars-say-thank-you
story: Lewis Ward, , owner of Saltire Mobile Valeting, visited the Haddington depot, located behind the townrsquos Tesco on Lydgait, on May .Lewis says he is now known locally as ldquothe bus stop guy, after an article about him cleaning bus shelters around Tranent, Ormiston, Elphinstone and Macmerry appeared in the Courier a few weeks ago.Lewis visited the depot and started washing staff membersrsquo cars without warning.He said: ldquoI went down and asked someone where the car park was for staff cars and they said it was round the corner. So I went round, pulled all the things out of the van and started washing them.ldquoI think the manager then came out and asked what was going on and what I was doing, and I told her I was showing my appreciation and saying thank you for all of the hard work they do.ldquoShe said it was a really nice thing to do and askedI needed anything. When I was done she askedwe could take some photos and they would bring the ambulances over.Lewis has dubbed his recent gesture his own version of the pm Clap for Carers and his own way of showing his appreciation.The former Ross High School pupil said: ldquoIt took me a few weeks to get things sorted but was well worth the wait to see some very happy faces.ldquoIt felt so much more rewarding than the bus stops. I think it was getting to see the workers face to face and say thank you.ldquoIt is what they all deserve. All of the guys at the depot were fairly chuffed.ldquoI even got a couple of messages from some of the guys at the depot afterwards to say thank you.He added: ldquoItrsquos got a good response on social media from people.ldquoDoing it all has actually made me busier. That wasnrsquot the plan, though ndash I just did it off my own back and to say thank you.He cleaned nine cars in total, using the same method as that for the bus shelters covering the cars in snow foam, brushing it in and washing it off.All of the vehicles received the full treatment, including getting tyres polished, the car waxed and alloys cleaned.He has now reopened his business but is working half shts and cleaning the van after every car, with the van also getting a deep clean every weekend.

title: stony-snake-slithers-way-wallyford
story: The colourful, creative design is giving youngsters added fun when they venture out for exercise each day during lockdown.The Knight family ndash Jack, , twins Kayden and Kai, aged eight, and their sister five-year-old Lily ndash launched the project which involves placing painted stones to form Wally the snakersquos body.Their mum, Sam Wylie, , of Inchview Crescent, got the idea, via social media, from a similar project in Prestonpans.The children painted stones from the garden and placed them to start off the design on the ground near the local library and office at Wallyford Primary School in Futures Way.They are now hoping other youngsters will follow suit by adding their colourful stones to make the snake even bigger.Sam said: ldquoI thought it was a fun thing for children to do while they are out for a walk.ldquoMine get so excited to see how many other stones have been placed there.Mhairi Stretton, headteacher at Wallyford Primary School, tweeted: ldquoWas lovely to stop and look at all the stones left on Wally.ldquoChildrenrsquos names, school values, messages of love, kindness and hope.ldquoReopening the building means so much in so many ways. Team Wallyford.

title: east-lothian-council-monks-retreat-plans
story: Parts of Monkton House, on the outskirts of Musselburgh, date back to the th century and its current owners spent decades restoring the property.Now they have been given planning permission to turn it into self-catering accommodation which will be aimed at large family gatherings of up  people at a time.Among the work carried out by the owners is a stunning Chinese drawing room complete with dragon wall paintings and a ceiling fresco, and an expressionist-style bathroom suite.Planning permission has been granted for the main house and a detached cottage to be turned into guest accommodation by East Lothian Council planners.There were no objections from the public.And it raised no concerns with Historic Environment Scotland or council departments.Until the late th century,Monkton House was used as a safe house for monks at Newbattle Abbey before becoming a family home. A tower on the site dates back to the th century but the gardens are thought to have been established after it was a private residence in the th and th century.

title: letter-taking-childs-gnome-no-joke
story: In order to win the garden gnome, you had to guess the name.So my son guessed the name Tommy, after his grandad who died of cancer in .Imagine our delight when the school phoned us to say we had guessed the correct name and, since then, Tommy the garden gnome has taken pride of place in our garden.On Monday, June , some heartless person took it from our garden and our son was deeply upset, for sentimental reasons.Then, on Saturday, June , we received an envelope through our door with photographs of Tommy in ious locations and a letter saying we were to collect him from our local train station ndash but when we went up, nothing was there.By this time, our son was deeply upset that someone could be so cruel, so we took the reluctant step and got the police involved for the sake of our son.Then we woke up on Sunday morning, the next day, and discovered Tommy was back in our garden.Whoever did this should be ashamed of themselves as, whilst it might have been a joke to them, the gnome has sentimental value for us and we took it deadly seriously.Alan LoughBoroughdalesDunbar

title: community-council-elections-hold-year
story: Elections usually take place every four years but, amid the coronavirus pandemic, East Lothian Council has decided to postpone the elections until October .There are  community councils in the county, from Musselburgh and Inveresk, and Whitecraig in the west to Dunbar and East Lammermuir in the east.Returning officer Monica Patterson, who took the decision to postpone the elections, said: ldquoApart from the obvious practical reasons for postponement, we strongly believe it would be beneficial to have continuity of community council membership to support and guide the invaluable community resilience work during the recovery phase expected to extend into next year.ldquoI would like to take this opportunity to thank all of our community councils for their continued support and assistance theyrsquore providing in their local communities at this time.Meanwhile, North Berwick Community Council is seeking dedicated and hardworking iniduals from their area with time to spare to fill its two vacancies. For further information and to express an interest, email secretary@northberwickcommunity council.org

title: choir-sing-thanks-community-raise-up
story: during the global pandemic.East Linton Community Choir had been due to perform at the end of March.However, Covid- saw the concerts cancelled so, instead, the members created their own version of You Raise Me Up, previously performed bymusicians ranging from Josh Groban to Aled Jones and Westle.Lorraine Cormack, conductor of the choir, which has been running for  years, said: ldquoEarlier this year, in March, the choir were meant to perform attheir annual concerts but due to the lockdown they could not.ldquoObviously, they were disappointed, so I decided to offer them a challenge.ldquoI sent them music and asked them to learn their part in the song and then send me a recording of them singing it.ldquoThis was no mean feat because it probably involved new technology to them.ldquoI then mixed all the tracks together on my computer and came up with this final version.ldquoWhat inspired the choir to do this was to thank all the local shops, businesses, volunteers, friends and neighbours who have been supporting EastLinton throughout the coronavirus and, probably, will have to do so for some time tocome.ldquoWe hope you like this track, so... East Linton, thank you.The choir has more than  members who, before the coronavirus, met in East Linton Community Hall each Wednesday evening.In , the choir hosted a concert on the last weekend of March which saw such high demand for tickets that, since then, the group have addedmore performances to the annual concert.Lorraine, who set up the choir after moving to the village, was pleased with howthe finished version of their recorded song turned out.She told the Courier feedback had been positive and said: ldquoIt has been absolutely amazing.ldquoWe are quite a small, reliant wee village and the local Co-op went above and beyond what I am sure theywere asked to do.ldquoThey were delivering on foot to people that could not go out and all of us are so reliant on the local pharmacyand surgery.ldquoWe thought it was good to tell these people that we are very grateful.The video has been viewed more than , times online.To hear East Linton Lockdown Choirrsquos version of the song on YouTube, go to shorturl.at hkD

title: torness-donates-money-foodbanks
story: Torness Power Station staff gave their support to East Lothian Foodbank and Dunbar Basics Bank.A number of face masks were also given to the Dunbar group for volunteers to use during their duties.And a further pound has been given to Aberlour childrenrsquos charity, which runs a respite and support service in Prestonpans.Robert Gunn, station director at Torness, to the south-east of Dunbar, was happy to help.He said: ldquoThe Covid- pandemic has affected everyone, leaving some in need of support more than ever.ldquoThese organisations carry out a crucial role in the local community and Irsquom glad we have been able to help them in this way.In April, the Tranent-based East Lothian Foodbank gave out  three-day emergency food parcels, feeding nearly  people.More than a third of those receiving support were children.Candace Higgins, East Lothian Foodbank director, appreciated the donation.She said: ldquoThis is a dficult time for everyone but particularly for those in need.ldquoDealing with this crisis whilst worrying about how you are going to feed your family is frankly terrying.ldquoWe have been fortunate enough to have been able to stay open to help support our community and this has been due to the overwhelming public support we have received.ldquoThis generous donation will allow us to continue providing this much needed service and takes away any worry we have about being able to do this.

title: fraser-centre-receives-funding-boost
story: The Corra Foundation awarded the centre pound,, while the second grant of pound, came from the Bank of Scotland Foundation.A spokesperson for the centre said: ldquoThese grants are extremely important to The Fraser Centre Community Trust during this closure and are gratefully appreciated.The Fraser Centre, located on Winton Place, closed its doors on March , a decision staff say they did not take lightly.Its doors remain closed and there is no date set for reopening, although centre staff say they hope to do so in phase three of the Scottish Governmentrsquos plan to ease lockdown restrictions.Staff continue to monitor government guidance and will update the community in due course.However, they have warned that some events may be able toquicker than others, and all will be subject to new restrictions to comply with health guidance.While the centre has been closed, several groups based in the building have moved online.Groups such as senior Pilates, the dementia friendship group and arts group now hold classes on Zoom.Anyone looking for more information can contact tine.breusch@gmail for Pilates, sue@dfel.org.uk for the dementia group or david@the frasercentre for the arts group.Anyone who wishes to discuss ideas for an event or activity can contact David Orr, site manager, on david@thefrasercentreFor more information and updates on The Fraser Centre, visit www. facebook The-Fraser-Centre

title: coronavirus-contact-tracing-scheme-safe-says-msp
story: Highlighting the role of contact tracers in the scheme, Colin Beattie said he understood that people may be worried about the risks of potential phone scams.But he stressed: ldquoThe NHS already has a number of protections in place to stop potential fraudsters and ensure all information is kept confidential.He said Test and Protect would help the Scottish Government to gradually change the restrictions that help to suppress Covid-, so society could adapt to ldquoa new normal.Those who experience any one of the symptoms ndash a high temperature, a new continuous cough or a loss of or change to sense of smell or taste ndash must immediately self-isolate for a minimum of seven days.As soon as they start showing symptoms they should go to www.nhsinform.scot or call    to arrange to be tested.When contacting iniduals who have tested positive, contact tracers will ask people to identy others with whom theyrsquove been in close contact and places theyrsquove been from  hours prior to the onset of symptoms up until they self-isolated.This information will then be input to contact tracing software and used to find and contact those identied.The positive inidual will not be named by the contact tracer, in line with patient confidentiality, unless they agree to have their details disclosed to help the contact tracing process.The data gathered will be stored securely by NHS Scotland and safely destroyed as soon as possible after the pandemic concludes.Mr Beattie, who also represents Midlothian North, added: ldquoContact tracers will introduce themselves, state the reason for their call and will always identy who they are calling by name.ldquoThey will not ask for information about bank accounts or medical records, and they will not try to sell you anything.ldquoThe tracers will be supported by software which builds on a tried and trusted , allowing teams to identy outbreaks and reduce transmission for high risk groups here in Midlothian and East Lothian.ldquoTrace and Protect is one way we will tackle this pandemic, but physical distancing and good hand hygiene continues to play a huge role as minimise the spread of infection.

title: community-resilience-volunteers-aberlady-dirleton-north-berwick
story: From collecting shopping and vital prescriptions to dog walking and simply being there for people, the volunteers are there for residents throughout the coronavirus crisis.Here, we look at fourof the groups who are giving up their own time to help out.AberladySINCE the middle of March, a squad of volunteers have offered assistance to people who have needed shopping and prescriptions collected, as well as dogs walked.But visitors have continued to flood into Aberlady after lockdown restrictions were eased.Ian Malcolm, from the community resilience team, said little had changed in the village from a community resilience point of view.However, he highlighted it was increasingly busy at weekends, with people visiting the village and the local nature reserve.Ian said there were also a number of people parking illegally.Anyone needing help collecting shopping or prescriptions, or any other assistance during the continued lockdown, should contact Ian on   or Sam Robertson on  .Further information is available online at www.facebook Aberlady-Resilience-DirletonVOLUNTEERS working to help people throughout Dirleton have been thanked.Dirleton Area Resilience Teamfinished off National Volunteer Week, which took place June -, thanking the team of volunteers.During the coronavirus lockdown, helpers have undertaken more than  activities, including dog walking, shopping and collections of prescriptions.David Tait, DART lead co-ordinator, said: ldquoSpecial events have included a surprise visit by the Easter Bunny, the distribution of craft packs to children within the Dirleton area and the introduction of lockdown treats from DART to residents every fortnight.ldquoWe have seen the development of the D-Art Gallery by junior DART, and teenagers undertaking the Saltire Award, who have been busy baking.ldquoThanks also to all the people behind the scenes ndash those who are tirelessly cooking and baking to ensure a ready supply of soups, crumbles and cakes for the larder the area co-ordinators the finance convenor the DART editor, who regularly produces our newsletter and has recently designed our new website and the DART craft group, who are busy making face coverings.However, the group is also looking to the future, with strategic forward planning on how to move ahead as lockdown eases.David told the Courier that the team were trying to plan for every eventuality ndash working in partnership with the Scottish Government, East Lothian Council, the local community council and other agencies.Together, they hope to ensure that support, resources and provisions are in place for the benefit of the community.David added: ldquoWe think it is clear that, even when lockdown allows further easing, there will be a need for further support within the community. We aim to have that support in place when it is required.DART community essentials larder will continue to be a critical asset for the community, with the support date pushed back to October.If anyone has any comments about DART or requirements for support, please get in contact by email to DART.Coordinators@outlook or visit the website at dirletonresilience.orgDunbarORGANISATIONS continue to come together to help people needing assistance in Dunbar.The townrsquos community council has been heavily involved in the community resilience efforts throughout Dunbar and West Barns.Meanwhile, Home-Start East Lothian has been working to ensure hot meals are sent out to those in need.A weekly report noted there continued to be ldquoa small increase in the demand, with the group now working with families to enable them to start cooking for themselves, by reducing meals and instead providing a midweek store cupboard bag, with recipes and ingredients.Home-Start East Lothian is also working alongside the Fareshare Hub in Port Seton to provide the majority of the food, with donations also being made from other groups, including Shikz Ltd, Prestonpans.Mungoswells Malt and Milling also donated flour, which Dunbar Community Bakery turned into  loves, so people received a fresh loaf along with margarine and teabags.Meanwhile, other services, including collecting shopping and prescriptions, as well as dog walking, have continued.The appeal for laptops and tablets is also ongoing.George Robertson, chairman of Dunbar and East Linton Area Partnership, said: ldquoThe appeal for redundant laptops and tablets is going well, with about  devices ready for new homes.ldquoThese are being offered to the schools and any not required by them will be offered to community groups and youth clubs.ldquoEach device requires a fair bit of work. Some need minor repairs or upgrades, some arrive without power supplies and replacements have to be ordered.ldquoA few are dead on arrival or cannot be repurposed and these are broken down for spare parts.ldquoAll are thoroughly cleaned and sterilised, and the entire contents of the hard drive are wiped before being reinstalled with Linux Mint operating system. Those without Bluetooth are being fitted with a Bluetooth dongle.ldquoAs a result, these machines are all given a new lease of le and are able to access Google Classroom and all other educational software.ldquoInternet access is either via wi-fi or,that is not available, by linking to a smartphone via Bluetooth.North BerwickNORTH Berwick Coastal Community Connectionswas set up by the North Berwick Health and Wellbeing Association last year.Tillie Baird and Deborah Ritchie, co-chairs of the North Berwick Coastal Health and Wellbeing Association, said a key part of the project had been a link with the team at North Berwick Health Centre to help people who were suffering from the poor health effects of social isolation.A year ago it appointed Carol Stobie as a project worker and, since then, she has connected nearly  local adults with local gatherings and activities, including the projectrsquos own Scone Cafeweekly drop-ins.During the Covid- crisis, Carol has kept members connected through telephone befriending and a monthly newsletter.On June , NBCCC will be holding its AGM and it is hoping to appoint co-chairpersons to share its leadership role, as well as a secretary, treasurer and task group convenors to lead on specic areas of work such as fundraising, befriending, and becoming a charity.Carol said Community Connections was also part of the North Berwick Community Emergency Resilience Plan.ldquoOur focus is on social and emotional support and we are supporting our volunteer connectors in offering a telephone befriending service to our clients during this period, she said.ldquoWe will continue to take new referrals of clients who need this service in the North Berwick Coastal area, as long as we have volunteer capacity.For more information and to receive a Zoom invitation to the AGM, email Carol at nbc-communityconnections@outlook or telephone her on  .As usual,residents need help with shopping or prescriptions they can visit the resilience teamrsquos dedicated website at www.nbresilience or phone  .

title: community-resilience-volunteers-dunpender-gifford-haddington
story: From collecting shopping and vital prescriptions to dog walking and simply being there for people, the volunteers are there for residents throughout the coronavirus crisis.Here, we look at three of the groups who are giving up their own time to help out.DunpenderVOLUNTEERS continue to offer a range of services throughout East Linton and surrounding villages.Judith Priest, chairwoman of Dunpender Community Council, which also covers neighbouring Tyninghame and Whitekirk, said little had changed and services were still on offer.Information relating to the coronavirus can be found at www.tyninghamevillagehall.org.uk or by going to www.eastlinton.ukPeople can also contact   or  .GfordA GIFFORD Larder is coming to the village after a private donation towards the efforts of the resilience team.Gford Community Council said it received a ldquokind offer to help establish the new larder.And it revealed it has received additional funds of pound, from Corra Foundation, which will ensure that the Soup and a Smile project can continue into the summer.A community council spokesperson said: ldquoSome weeks ago we received a kind offer of a private donation to help establish a Gford Larder. towards our Soup and a Smile project.ldquoWith shielding households now continuing until the end of July, and restrictions likely for vulnerable households, this service remains an important way to combat social isolation.ldquoWe are really grateful for the certainty it offers us in the months ahead.The community council held its first online meeting this week, after suspending them during the
