contact: Jo Allen, on   or chairgfordcc@gmail Adam White, on   or adamjswhite@outlook Wendy Ferguson, on   or wendyferguson.wf@gmail or the Rev Aniko Schuetz Bradwell, on   or anikoschuetzbradwell@churchofscotland.org.ukHaddingtonA SPECIAL library is being set up to provide people with entertainment during lockdown.Haddingtonrsquos resilience group is launching a new initiative which will see people given the chance to read books, complete jigsaws and games.The Haddington Lending Library is expected to be launched this week and Chris McEwan, vice-chairman of the townrsquos community council, was among those cataloguing the ious books, games and DVDs.He said: ldquoWe got funding from supporting communities as part of the resilience team for us to set up a lending library.ldquoThis past week, we have been gathering donations, buying stuff and getting things altogether.ldquoWe are cataloguing it and hoping to launch some time this week to allow people to go and check out books, jigsaws and games so that we can deliver them to people who are isolating or donrsquot want to go out and get books and stuff.ldquoWe are going to see how well it goes and how successful it becomes and maybe try to continue on with it, going forward.A website is being created for the project, which was the idea of Pat Lemmon, who is also part of the community council and resilience team.Nearly  books have already been donated, with  jigsaws and  DVDs. Each of the items will go through a y process of being sanitised to ensure they are clean before they are loaned.Chris added: ldquoThe lending library will be there not just for people isolating but for families who are starting to struggle to know what to do.ldquoThatrsquos why we have got games and DVDs.Chris said services such as collecting shopping and prescriptions were continuing but, like many other resilience groups across the county, it was quieter compared with earlier in lockdown.As part of the launch, the group have asked members of the public for impressive pictures of Haddington.Pat said there had been more than  entries into the competition.Those were whittled down to just , with members of the public voting on which image they would like to see transformed into a jigsaw.She said: ldquoThe winner gets a copy of the jigsaw to keep and a copy will go into the lending library.ldquoFour runners up will have a copy of their picture turned into a jigsaw and put into the lending library as well.ldquoIt is something we hope to add to and people love jigsaws.

title: scotlands-lockdown-easing-scottish-spca-advice-dog-owners-know
story: Before tighter measures were introduced, most dogs were likely suited to the routine of their owners ndash which included being left indoors while they went out for work.But since March, thousands more people in Scotland have been working from home.The immediate impact would, of course, prove to be popular with your four-legged friend ndash however animal experts are warning of the consequences once lockdown ends.Speaking to Radio Clyde News, Alan Grant from the Scottish SPCA said there will likely be ldquoteething problems for dogs as measures ease further and office working s.He told the radio station: ldquoDogs are much like us, any change to the routine or their day-to-day le is going to have an impact on them.ldquoWersquove all had to change and work from home and adapt our working protocols, which has been dficult for us at the beginning but wersquore now more used to it. Itrsquos the same for the dogs.ldquoDogs may have been a bit unsettled at the beginning with the owners being there but theyrsquove now adapted to that situation ndash and itrsquos now about adapting to going back to the old situation of the owner not being there, and thatrsquos where there will be a bit of teething problems for a lot of people at the beginning.The Scottish SPCA have urged owners to start with "micro" changes now- leaving their dogsfor a short period of time with something to keep them occupied.They also suggest investing in a camera to have a greater understanding of your dogs behaviour when you are not there.Mr Grant continued: "We want to start right now with very small changes, we call it stress inoculation. If we never leave our dogs, theyrsquore never going to get used to it."So we would leave them for micro amounts of time ndash but wersquod do a lot of stuff before we went to leaving them."Wersquod look at their day-to-day le and how can we make that le more enriching."Are they food motivated  If so, can we give them something that will take them five or ten minutes to eat, while we leave for five or ten minutes ndash then see how they are."Something  that is a great idea is to get a camera and see how your dog is actually behaving when you go out."That way yoursquoll know whether they go sleep for half an hour and then get up and start panting or is it immediately when we leave."Mr Grant told the radio stationit is "imporant" to know how your dog reacts to being left on its own.He continued: "If they are confident being left on their own for a short while, then we probably donrsquot need to deal with separation anxiety because they can cope being left."If that is the case, we just need to build up on that time that they are on their own."Something like getting a camera can be very much to your advantage so we know what we are dealing with ndash perhaps revealing that they can cope fine but just get bored, so we can enrich their le and give them other things to do so that they are not as bored when you go out."This likely means your dog suffers from seperation anxiety.Symptoms of this includeyour dog starts pacing and panting the moment you leave the door.In that case, Mr Grant says, you "would maybe need to look at some form of tailored programme for your particular dogthat is the case ndash but without knowing that itrsquos very hard to make that call."You can find our more information from the Scottish SPCA here.

title: vandals-target-historic-cross
story: The vandalism, thought to have happened on Saturday night, was condemned by Councillor Stuart Currie who received messages from constituents about the incident the following day.He said: "This act of vandalism is an utter disgrace. There are so many people working hard to make our town better and then idiots come along looking for any excuse to try and damage a local landmark."I was contacted on Sunday and got in touch with council officers who are taking action to remove the graffiti whilst ensuring the stone is not damaged. I very much hope that the CCTV has captured those responsible and they are punished accordingly."A spokesperson for East Lothian Council said: ldquoUnfortunately there was some graffiti on the Mercat Cross in Musselburgh which has now been cleaned off by the council. This is a criminal offence and we work with police and partner agencies to trace and prosecute anyone responsible for this type of crime where possible.The th century Mercat Cross, where markets were traditionally held and proclamations made, is situated near the Old Town Hall in the High Street.It stands on the site of the original medieval cross and, from a square pedestal, three steps rise to a Tuscan shaft of the late th century, supporting a lion and the burgh arms.The monument was focal point for proclamations as part of the turf cutting ceremony during the  Riding of the Marches which takes place in Musselburgh every  years.Police Scotland said it had no reports of the vandalism, which is not thought to have any links to any national cause or campaign such as Black Lives Matter.

title: disgraceland
story: The once busy go-karting track has lain empty since the Gladsmuir venue shut down in January .And, during lockdown, it has become a magnet for fly-tippers with piles of household and industrial waste dumped all across the site.The main building has been set alight and all that is left a burnt-out shell with pieces of the roof and walls hanging perilously from it.Rubbish ranging from a childrsquos paddling pool to household furnishing and gas canisters lie strewn across the complex amid reports that youths have been congregating at the site and racing cars on it, despite the crumbling tracks.Iain Gray, East Lothian MSP, said: ldquoThis really is a dangerous disgrace. It is an eyesore, but more to the point, it is clear that young people have been using the site to meet up, and to race, and someone is going to be hurt sooner or later."The owners need to make this site secure and urgently.Raceland closed its doors in January  after nearly  years in East Lothian.The land was bought by Euro Garages Ltd which currently has a joint planning application alongside McDonalds Restaurants to create a service station with drivethru restaurant and coffee shop facilities on the land.Ward Councillor Colin McGinn was disappointed to learn of the condition of the unsecured site.He said: ldquoI am really disappointed to hear this has become an issue.ldquoI would think from an environmental health point of view it is up to the owner to take all reasonable measures to secure the site and as for any waste I would assume they would again be responsible for removing any waste that has been dumped on their land.ldquoI have asked that council officers contact the owners and also to check on signage that is required warning of any dangers to trespassers that said I also believe that the public have a role to play here in disposing of their waste in the correct manner and not simply dumping it in our countryside.East Lothian Council said it had placed notices warning that the building was dangerous but would carry out another inspection to ensure they were still there and contact the owners asking them to secure the site.A spokesperson said: ldquoThe responsibility for ensuring safety and security of the site lies with the owner.ldquoCouncil building standards would generally deal with possible dangers from unsafe buildings affecting people passing by and going about their normal business as opposed to those who access the premises and who shouldnrsquot be there.ldquoWe will get in touch with the owners to advise the property is open and seethey can secure it.ldquoThe council already have lsquodangerous buildingrsquo notices posted around the site but a further site visit will be carried out to see they are still in place.Euro Garages Ltd did not respond to a request to comment.

title: iain-gray-retire-east-lothians-msp

title: floral-display-gains-tv-stars-seal-approval
story: TV presenter and naturalist Chris Packham praised the colourful planting surrounding the townrsquos iconic golf ball sculpture at the Levenhall roundabout, which contains a mix of Scottish wildflowers.Species include yarrow, cornflower, wild carrot, viperrsquos bugloss, corn marigold, hawkbit, ox-eye daisy, corn poppy, cowslip, primrose, meadow buttercup, yellow rattle, hedge woundwort, devilrsquos-bit scabious and dandelion.Referring to a video of the display on social media, Mr Packham, the co-presenter of the BBCrsquos nature programmes Springwatch, Autumnwatch and Winterwatch, tweeted: ldquoEvery council across the UK should aspire to this ndash itrsquos beautul and productive and what people want from a new normal for wildle and the environment. Top work Musselburgh!An East Lothian Council spokesperson said: ldquoIn recent years, East Lothian Council has created and managed a number of wildflower sites across the county to increase bioersity within towns and villages.ldquoThe wildflowers currently visible at the roundabout on Haddington Road, Musselburgh, have self-seeded from previous yearsrsquo sowing and have been appreciated for their colourful display by both local residents and visitors.ldquoSome of the wildflower sites in East Lothian form part of the John Muir Pollinator Way, which aims to create habitat for pollinators along the entire -mile route of the John Muir Way.ldquoThis initiative, developed by Bugle UK, identies where wildflower forage and nesting habitats for pollinators and other wildle can be created, enhanced and managed along the John Muir Way, including on school grounds, golf courses, cemeteries and public parks, and included wildflower sowing at Prestongrange Museum last year.Irene Tait, chairperson of Musselburgh  Inveresk Community Council, said: ldquoIt is stunning and has really taken off this year. title: houses-dress-tranent-childrens-gala-day
story: The competition was also given a touch of mystery this year, as the entrants were judged by an independent and anonymous group, rather than the gala committee.Derek Ross, gala committee chairman, said: ldquoWe werenrsquot doing the judging because there wasnrsquot a gala court this year.ldquoIt was an independent party that approached us and askedthey could take the judging on, and they judged it anonymously.The judges, who the Courier can reveal were Radio Saltirersquos Davie Martin and former gala committee member Colin McGinn, looked at online pictures of the houses entered into the competition, and also separately visited the homes to view them.Mr Martin said: ldquoThe committee couldnrsquot judge the competition so we approached them and said we would be happy to do it anonymously.ldquoColin and I looked at the homes separately, marked them out of , then emailed the results to each other -- we hit send at the same time so we couldnrsquot change our mind!ldquoThe circus theme won by just one point.And winning brothers Hayden and Cole McLay were unaware that their circus-themed house on The Heugh had won, until mum Michelle saw the announcement on Facebook.Mrs McLay said: ldquoMy boys were going to be in the gala: Hayden, , was going to be a herald and Cole, , was chosen to be a page boy.Gala court members traditionally dress their homes, with parents and carers getting stuck in and assisting the children.This year, some six houses were dressed up, with themes including a safari, a sweetie shop and movies Frozen and Trolls, before participants were initially told the competition would be cancelled.Mrs McLay said: ldquoWe were told the best dressed house wasnrsquot going ahead but we didnrsquot want to disappoint the boys so we decided to go ahead and dress our house anyway. We did a carnival circus theme we had a bouncy castle, hook-the-duck, tin can alley, popcorn and candy floss machines, hot dogshellipldquoAnd then we were informed there would be independent judges coming out to judge the house.She added: ldquoWe only knew we won because it was posted on the gala Facebook page.The Facebook post by Mr Ross said: ldquoI have been informed by the independent judges that it was a very close call but the winner of the best decorated house is The Circus: Hayden McLayand Cole McLay .ldquoWell done to all that took part in these dficult times. title: westminster-recognition-spurs-fundraising-mum
story: Kayleigh Jamieson-Tait had taken on a challenge to run , miles to raise money for Edinburgh Childrenrsquos Hospital Charity as Edinburghrsquos Royal Hospital for Sick Children had supported her son Jack, who has asthma.And she vowed to carry on towards her goal by swapping the road for a static bicycle after the family were forced to isolate because of the youngsterrsquos condition.Now, East Lothian MP Kenny MacAskill has paid tribute to the mum-of-two, from Macmerry, for her determination as she revealed she is more than half way towards her goal.And in an Early Day Motion lodged at Westminster, Mr MacAskill also wished Jack, who turns  in December, a happy birthday in advance.Delighted Kayleigh said the public praise had come at just the right time, as she was struggling to stay motivated during the current crisis.She said: ldquoJack is  in December and I said I would do  miles for every year he has been with us. I had hoped to finish in September but the lockdown changed it.ldquoThere have been ups and downs and sometimes it is hard to stay motivated.ldquoThis motion is just the boost I needed and I am delighted by the recognition.Macmerry Primary School pupil Jack was first diagnosed with asthma when he was just three months old, and had been visiting the Royal Hospital for Sick Children every few months for treatment.During lockdown, however, most appointments have been carried out online.Mum Kayleigh said he had had to make one hospital trip but it had been stressful.She said: ldquoIt was so dficult and strange because normally there would be other children running around and that wasnrsquot the case this time.She has now clocked up  miles of her epic trek and aims to complete it in time for Jackrsquos birthday.Mr MacAskillrsquos Early Day Motion stated: ldquoThat this House recognises the efforts of Kayleigh Jamieson-Tait from Macmerry who is currently in the midst of cycling , miles on her exercise bike at home while in lockdown to raise money for Edinburgh Childrenrsquos Hospital Charity and to mark her son Jackrsquos th birthday congratulates her on raising over pound to date acknowledges the work done by that charity in supporting Jack and many other children who require hospital care across Scotland wishes Kayleigh luck in completing her mileage and fundraising goals and wishes Jack a very happy th birthday.To support Kayleigh go to www.justgiving fund raising kayleigh-jamieson-tait

title: drivers-blocking-county-coastal-roads-asked-think-others
story: East Lothianrsquos scenic coastline has been flooded with visitors from throughout the county and beyond since lockdown restrictions were relaxed at the end of last month.However, with cars lining many roads, Dunbar Coastguard have urged people to be more considerate.Teams of Coastguard volunteers from throughout East Lothian have spent recent weekends carrying out ldquoaccident prevention surveillance patrols.A spokesman for the Dunbar crew said: ldquoDespite local media attention recently, cars were found to be obstructing coastal access roads that may be needed by emergency services.ldquoWhilst it is nice to enjoy our beautul coastline now that lockdown restrictions have eased, please think of others and consider the consequences of your actions.ldquoFurther preventative patrols will be considered in the coming weeks, taking into account any changes to lockdown restriction, weather conditions and any particular hazards we are made aware of.ldquoIf you see someone in dficulty or something you are concerned about on the shoreline, beaches, clfs, mud or water, call  immediately and ask for the Coastguard.

title: swim-club-pools-together-cash-boost
story: The club applied for financial support from the Swimathon Foundationrsquos Covid- Relief Fund.With the coronavirus outbreak preventing the use of swimming pools, the club has been holding quizzes and games nights, as well as putting land training sessions out via social media.The clubrsquos Lyn Taylor said: ldquoDue to Covid-, our fundraising has had to be paused, as lots of our events are at galas and supermarkets, so the funding from Swimathon has been very welcome.ldquoIt will kick start the funds for the next season when, hopefully, we will be back in the pool. title: phase-2-13-new-changes-scotlands-lockdown-restrictions-eased
story: Throughout the last week, the First Minister had indicated her optimism at moving the country into Phase  of the four-phased route map out of lockdown restrictions.The decision was made at the three-weekly formal review of the measures, following a further suppression of the coronavirus in Scotland ndash with the NRS revealing yesterday the number of virus-related deaths fell for the seventh week in a row.But what does Phase  actually mean for you From seeing family and friends to outdoor shopping, here are the biggest changes from the latest easing of lockdown.Shielding peopleFrom today, people who are shielding can go outdoors for exercise.Shielding people can also take part in non-contact outdoor activity, such as golf, from tomorrow.From tomorrow, people who are shielding can also meet people from one other household.Seeing friends and familyThe First Minister today revealed people can enter other households to use the toilet - but should continue meeting outdoors.You will also be able to meet with larger groups including family and friends outside - with the maximum of  extra households and  people.This is in addition to the measures from Phase , which included sunbathing sitting outdoors, and visiting other households outdoors and in gardens.Extended householdFrom tomorrow, people who live alone or with children under  can have a bubble with one other household - you can visit indoors and stay overnight.This has to be with this household onlyTransportPublic transport can increase their capacity but will remain signicantly limited to allow for physical distancing.Face masks will be mandatory on all public transport.The First Minister says the five mile limit for leisure and recreational purposes will remain for now - "remain as close as possible to local area" until Phase There is no five-mile limit for visiting family and friends.DentistsAll dental practices can reopen to see patients with urgent care needs from Phase  ndash meanwhile procedures which generate aerosols will remain at emergency dental hubs.SportsThe guidance also says the resumption of professional sport, in line with public health advice, is allowed.As with the previous Phase, unrestricted outdoors exercise is permitted, so long as you adhere to distancing measures. Non-contact sports like golf, hiking, fishing etc remain allowed.However, gyms will not be able to reopen until Phase .WorshipThe route map also says places of worship will be able to reopen for private prayer - but not for extended groups until Phase .ShoppingOutdoor markets can also reopen, provided there can be controls on the number of people within the market and distancing is kept.The First Minister also outlined plans fornon-essential retail units to reopen form June - but these will have to have outside entrances. Therefore shopping centres cannot reopen.Drive-thrus and garden centres were already permitted to reopen under the previous easing of measures.SportsSports courts and playgrounds are now permitted to reopen across Scotland.WorkingWorking from home remains the default position.But the guidance says non-essential indoor, non-office based workplaces can reopen - including factories, warehouses, lab and research facilities.The construction sector can also implement further stages of a phased .There can also be a relaxation of restriction on housing moves.MarriagesUnder Phase , marriages and civil partnerships can take place in Scotland with the number of attendees kept to a minimal.Moving houseRelaxation on restrictions on housing moves.EducationCollege and university staff canto make essential preparations for restart in Phase .These institutionswill not until Phase , with schools set toacross Scotland from August .

title: community-resilience-volunteers-longniddry-aberlady-gullane-north-berwick
story: From collecting shopping and vital prescriptions to dog walking and simply being there for people, the volunteers are there for residents throughout the coronavirus crisis.Here, we look at fourof the groups who are giving up their own time to help out.LongniddryTHE resilience group in Longniddry has added to its service and begun delivering library books to village residents in their homes.The service is being run by the library in Port Seton Centre.The resilience teamrsquos general enquiries continue to come in, though residents are able to get food through online deliveries from both supermarkets and the local shop.In the past week, Longniddry Rotary Club facilitated the purchase of  activity packs, which went out to children in the village, as well as those in Cockenzie and Port Seton, alongside breakfast packs.The packs included modelling clay and acrylic paint for rock painting.Those who need assistance are asked to call Sheila Jamieson on  .Residents in Longniddry can also benefit from the food pantry in the Port Seton Centre.The pantry is open pm-pm Monday to Friday. Delivery can be arranged by calling  .There is also a food pantry at the Pennypit in Prestonpans, available am-pm.AberladyAS THE Scottish Governmentrsquos lsquotest and protectrsquo strategy begins to take effect, Aberladyrsquos community resilience team has been working to ensure it will have enough volunteers to cope with an anticipated increase in people asked to self-isolate.Ian Malcolm, from the team, said it had carried out an assessment of the level of help which would be required, along with looking at the possibility some volunteers will be ing to work.He said: ldquoOne of the things we have been doing is assessing levels and we can say that for, the foreseeable future, we have sufficient volunteers and have a lot of help.The volunteers have been offering a range of services to people who are stuck at home or vulnerable, from collecting shopping and presciptions to walking their dogs.Anyone needing help collecting shopping or prescriptions, or any other assistance during the continued lockdown, should contact Ian on   or Sam Robertson on  .Further information is available online at www.facebook Aberlady-Resilience-GullaneWITH Scotland about to begin phase two of the lockdown exit strategy, the Gullane resilience group says it is beginning to see signs of ato normality.Food shopping, prescription deliveries and dog walking services continue to be offered but the focus is now more on the village hall hub activities.Every Tuesday between noon and pm and Friday between .am and .am the hub opens, with a range of services including food donations from Aldi for distributing, along with hearing aid batteries, craft materials, bread flours and yeast available for the commuity.It is also running a DVD, games, book and jigsaw exchange.Weekly themed craft packs available free for children in the village are proving popular, and fabric handed into the hall has enabled volunteers to make several styles of fabric face coverings, with donations going towards the East Lothian Foodbank.Anyone who needs assistance in Gullane is asked to telephone   or visit the web site at www.gullaneRT or the Facebook page ldquoGullane RT.North BerwickTHE North Berwick Community Emergency Resilience Team has been presented with a Rotary Community Service Recognition award by the Rotary Club of North Berwick.The -strong team of volunteers was set up and led by community councillor Sue Northrop, who holds responsibility for the community council emergency plan, and community council chairwoman Judy Lockhart in response to the Covid- pandemic.Rotary club president David Lancaster said the group had successfully identied inidual and group needs and, through its volunteers, delivered important assistance to the community.He said: ldquoWithout the many initiatives delivered by this group, a lot of people in our community would have been left in a desperate position as to how they could cope with the lockdown.ldquoWe wanted to recognise and thank Sue and Judy, for their leadership, the hard work of the organising group and also all of the volunteers. It has been an exceptional and successful effort.Judy said she was delighted with the award which recognised the amazing achievements of the group.She added: ldquoMost of us never knew each other before this but we have quickly become a team and worked closely together to help local people.Sue Northrop, the North Berwick Community Emergency Resilience Plan coordinator, said the group was amazingly creative and full of ideas.ldquoLinda Digney organises our cracking team of volunteers who shop and deliver prescriptions and kindness and Mairi McGinley set up and supports Street Links, people across North Berwick who connect with neighbours, she said.ldquoEmily Brunton manages our volunteers and the database and Maya Howell is business manager and runs the games and jigsaw exchange.ldquoKhlayre Cairney set up and runs the stitching team, making face coverings and Fiona Maciver set up the assets database and works with the North Berwick Trust on helping local businesses.ldquoDerek Selmes set up and supports our databases and records, and my husband, Alasdair Northrop, writes the weekly North Berwick Community Emergency Resilience Team update for the Courier and delivers  copies that we pay for to vulnerable residents every week with his delivery team.ldquoJudy has shown how multi-talented she is from helping to build our website from scratch to launching a fund which has raised almost pound,.As usual,residents need help with shopping or prescriptions they can go to www.nbresilience or phone  .

title: aim-half-pupils-back-school-day
story: The local authoritys chief education officer has said she is aiming to have  per cent of students in class at any given time when schools reopen in August.And while she admits it may not be possible at all schools, she has pledged to make sure all children are back on campuses "as soon as it is safe to do so".Parents across the county will be contacted next week with details of how the new school term will look for their children.Schools in East Lothian are expected to resume with in-service days on Monday, August  and Tuesday, August  before theof students on Wednesday, August .Lesley Brown said a staggering ,  responses were gathered from a parents survey the council carried out to gauge how families were feeling about the .The survey findings have not yet been made public however Mrs Brown said they had provided "very helpful" information to help them plan for schools reopening in August.And she urged parents to be patient.She said: "We are working closely with all headteachers on how we can safely bring children in to our school buildings for some in-school learning whilst also continuing with the learning at home."This will be very dferent for all of us and we understand that this model of lsquoblended learningrsquo will present a challenge for everyone including families in terms of work and childcare arrangements."Our in-school learning will be small groups of children coming in to school on a rota basis."Whilst we are aiming for  per cent of the school to be able to attend at any one time, in some of our primary and secondary schools this may not be possible."We understand that this will mean some continued disruption."I apologise for this but it is essential that we follow the physical distancing advice from the Scottish Government which means we are unable to have more children in school at the same time."The Scottish Government has outlined its commitment to ensuring that lsquoblended learningrsquo does not last longer than it needs to."We share this commitment and will follow all necessary guidance to bring all of our children and young people back to school as soon as it is safe to do so."

title: shielding-people-scotland-can-cannot-phase-2
story: As part of measures being eased as the country moved into Phase  of lockdown, Nicola Sturgeon revealed those people shielding would be among those to experience change immediately.There are around , people in the shielding group,which includes organ transplant recipients, those on active chemotherapy, those with severe lung disease, those with certain metabolic diseases, the signicantly immunosuppressed and pregnant women with underlying heart problems.They also included anyone primary care physicians deemed vulnerable.At the start of the pandemic they were all sent a letter telling them to stay indoors and take extra precautions until June .Last week, Nicola Sturgeon extended that, telling them that they would need to shield until the end of July.So what has changed for people shielding in Scotland Here we outline what you can and cannot do now we have moved into Phase .Irsquom in a shielding household, what CAN I do now Confirming her pledge last week, the First Minister revealed that anyone who is shielding , can nowgo outdoors for exercise ndash whether it be a walk, a wheel or cycle.But the First Minister added an extra easing. From today ndash Friday, June  ndash shielding people can also take part in non-contact outdoor activities.This includes things likegolf, fishingand hillwalking.Ms Sturgeon also revealed that those shielding can meet outdoors with people from one other household ndash however these are to be in groups of no more than eight.When you do go outside, you are urged to choose times and areas that are quiet ndash and wash your hands thoroughly as soon as you get back home.What can I still NOT do The First Minister urged people who are shielding to ldquocontinue to be extremely cautious ndash remaining at least  metres away from other people at all times, ldquoevenyou live with the person yoursquore out with.Unlike the general public, you cannot go inside someone rsquos house, or allow someone from another household to go inside yours ndash even to just use the toilet.What has the reaction been Brian Sloan, chief executive of Age Scotland, described the announcement as a ldquolight at the end of the tunnel for older people.He said: ldquoThe easing of lockdown for hundreds of thousands of older people living alone will come as a huge relief.ldquoSo many older people have endured lockdown without any face to face contact with family or friends for three months now, and it has been extremely dficult for them.ldquoFor the half a million over-s in Scotland who donrsquot use the internet, there hasnrsquot even been the option of video calls with loved ones. They have had to rely on the phone for conversation.ldquoThe result of such prolonged isolation is that loneliness levels are through the roof and having a profound impact on the mental and physical health of older people.He added: ldquoTodayrsquos announcement is a small step towards normality, and must of course be done in compliance with safety guidelines, but at last there is light at the end of the tunnel for our older people who have felt very cut off from society during this pandemic.ldquoThey can now look forward to seeing family and friends and when it is safe to do so, being part of their communities again.

title: coastal-car-parks-now-open
story: East Lothian Council had previously opened smaller car parks at local beauty spots but kept the larger beach car parks closed.However, it has now opened all its car parks and electronic signs have been installed on coastal roads warning people that public toilets remain closed and to stay local.Daily charges for using the car parks, which are in place at  popular beaches, are pound.In Gullane, where people have been continuing to visit the golden sands in good weather, residential streets closest to the shut beach-side car park have, at times, been very busy.So East Lothian Council is introducing temporary residents only access on some of the villages roads.With good weather predicted for the weekend, the council urged people to stick to the rules and only go to the coastit is within five miles of their homes.Councillor Norman Hampshire, depute council leader and cabinet spokesperson for the environment, warned that progress in the fight against Covid- remained "fragile".He said: "Progress in tackling COVID- is being made across Scotland. Irsquod like to thank the people of East Lothian for their support, patience and understanding throughout this period.ldquoItrsquos clear, however, that this progress remains fragile. The virus has taken its toll on far too many people and their families across the country."Our larger coastal car parks have re-opened ndash which is something I know many East Lothian local residents will welcome ndash but I would continue to urge everyone to remain in their local area as much as possible for outdoor leisure and exercise.ldquoWe have been taking a phased approach to re-opening and, given the instances of inappropriate parking on streets and roadsides observed during recent good weather, we believe it is appropriate for the larger car parks to now be open.ldquoIn line with government advice, public toilets remain closed.ldquoWe look forward to welcoming visitors from further afield to our coastal and countryside sites, and where in East Lothian, when it is safe to do so ndash you will receive a warm welcome."But at the moment we would ask that people do not travel for recreation from out withtheir local area, as requested by the Scottish Government."This will help avoid unnecessary travel or larger gatherings and put unnecessary pressure on infrastructure, which is particularly important at a time when progress in tackling COVID- remains so fragile.

title: new-bbc-documentary-series-jamie-genevieve-great-indoors-air-week

 staff affected by the decision will remain with the group but that  jobs are at risk.Quiz will look to buy back the stock and some of the assets from the Kast ision placed in administration for title: Opinion  Marianne Taylor  George Square needs to be completely overhauled - here   s why
story: The new station completely transforms the look and feel of this part of town. What a shame, then, about the second thing I couldnrsquot help noticing: how drab and disappointing George Square remains.Granted, the grim sight of loyalist protesters wrapped in Union flags ldquoprotecting the statues and Cenotaph didnrsquot help. But even without their isive presence the cityrsquos historic square is a let-down, visually, socially and culturally, a frustrating waste of urban space that could and should be far better utilised.Where other European squares create buzz and atmosphere with year-round arts, culture, food and shopping attracting locals and visitors, George Square is dreary and uninspiring: a few trees, some benches and a clutch of dull, predictable th-century statues ndash ldquogreat men and Queen Victoria ndash that few feel any kinship with. The only part of the square that has any real purpose and meaning is the Cenotaph.The idea that George Square is in serious need of a makeover is nothing new, of course, and there have been ious  dawns and broken promises over the years, not least the outrageous fiasco of  ndash remember that  ndash which wasted huge amounts of public money and goodwill alike. But the two defining events of  - coronavirus and the Black Lives Matter protests -offer Glasgow the best opportunity in a generation to finally get this right and transform George Square into the vibrant civic centre Glaswegians deserve.Letrsquos start with the pandemic, which will continue to damage the economic and social pull of town and city centres. As lockdown restrictions are gradually lted we will grasp a new reality ndash fewer shops, restaurants, bars and cultural attractions than before, with those that do re-open unable to work at full capacity for now. Answers to the sort of questions around attracting people to city centres that were already stumping businesses, planners and local authorities even before coronavirus hit have become all the more pressing.Thatrsquos where a proper revamp of George Square comes in, a key step forward in boosting Glasgowrsquos economy and cultural capital in the wake of the pandemic. What should the square contain  That would be for citizens to decide, but herersquos a few quick ideas that presume an eventual end to social distancing: an ampitheatre for live music, theatre and comedy, proper seating, pop-up pods for community groups, a food and craft market, arts and exhibition space, murals, a garden and childrenrsquos play area.As for the fate of the statues, again, it would be for the people to decide whether they still have a place in this new urban realm. Not that we would want to forget our past, of course. But surely we can find new and more creative ways to confront, commemorate and celebrate it, taking in voices that were previously ignored ndash women, ethnic minorities, working class people, gay people, the disabled ndash reflecting the ersity of our city as it is now.Rather than an expensive international competition for designs ndash letrsquos learn from  ndash a three-month public consultation could be held, and a  of local architects, planners, artists, businesspeople and community groups convened to create perhaps three dferent plans, which would then be voted on by the people of Glasgow. Granted, such an ambitious revamp wouldnrsquot be easy to fund in the dficult years ahead, but with a crucial economic and culturalat stake, it should be prioritised. Surely a mixture of public, private and philanthropic funding could be sourced Glasgow City Council has already started the conversation that could make all this happen, by bringing forward the pedestrianisation of George Square and suspending a third of city centre parking bays to make room for walkers and cyclists.I would urge council leader Susan Aitken and her team to think bigger. A commitment to redesign George Square would offer an exciting, positive and inclusive focus for Glaswegians in the tough months ahead. The end result could be what Glasgow has been crying out for for a generation: a proud and modern civic centrepiece that is worthy of our great city, a place that excites, entertains, and educates, that makes us feel part of something bigger. Wersquove never needed it more.All columnists are free to express their opinions. They donrsquot necessarily represent the view of The Herald.

title: Opinion  Iain Macwhirter  Swinney s school plan is not so much blended as half-baked
story: I donrsquot think this latter-day Rousseau really believed deschooling would actually happen. But in Scotland, thanks to Covid it could be within sight. Schoolrsquos out, not just for summer but for the foreseeable future.At least that was the educational prognosis from the Deputy First Minister, John Swinney, at the weekend. He announced a new ldquoblended learning, which sounds like something to do with tea, but is a euphemism for Scottish children spending most of the school week at home.:Opinion: Brian Beacom: Why I am edging slowly towards the pro-independence point of viewParents in Edinburgh were told that, when schools go back on August , theyrsquoll be lucky to see their children getting face-to-face teaching for a third of the time. Many Scottish pupils might only get one day a week. This is not so much blended as half-baked.Mr Swinney also endorsed the view of Larry Flanagan, general-secretary of the teachers union the EIS, that next yearrsquos exam diet should be cancelled, like this yearrsquos. Few in the education establishment much like competitive exams at the best of time, so it might seem unsurprising that they have been dropped ndash for the first time since .Parents, who donrsquot seem to have been consulted by Mr Swinneyrsquos misnamed Education Recovery Group, are furious. They see this as an abdication of responsibility by bureaucrats who care nothing about educational attainment and are putting the interests of their own client groups above the welfare of children.Parents in Edinburgh formed an instant pressure group,  , to demand proper, face-to-face education at least  per cent of the week. Sarah Chisnall says they also want serious benchmarked online learning for the other part of the ldquoblended learning experience, with a regular amount of teacher face time.Three months into school lockdown, it is surely a scandal that nothing of the like has been done. Home schooling is practically non-existent in many areas, according to parents, with some children having no contact with anything remotely resembling an actual teacher on line. Google, FIFA  and Instagram are poor substitutes.A UK-wide study from University College London confirmed yesterday that two million children across Britain have done little or no schoolwork at home during the lockdown. Four million have not had regular contact with a teacher and six million have not ed their most recent assignment.Nicola Sturgeon, who recognises a political disaster when she sees one, leaped in to try to undo the damage done by her deputy. ldquoIt is absolutely not the case that we are planning on blended learning to last a year or anything like it, she said on Monday, giving no guarantees that it wonrsquot.The First Minister promised that face-to face-teaching will happen ldquoas soon as possible. Exams will go ahead ndash well maybe ndash and she hinted that the two-metre rule in social distancing might be relaxed in schools.ldquoDelusional. said the SNPrsquos sometime coalition partners, the Scottish Greens, which has a lot of teachers amongst its membership. Like Larry Flanagan of the EIS they think next yearrsquos exams should be cancelled because there is no safe way of preparing children for them.Tell that to the parents. We know that the risk to children is vanishingly small. To prevent pupils spreading the disease to teachers and parents, schools could use masks, hand sanitisers, ldquobubble cohorts, and perspex screens.It is not aschildren arenrsquot associating already out of school. The extra transmission risk from a deep-cleaned environment like a school must surely be negligible. The risks of not going to school ndash mental health, obesity, domestic abuse and the like ndash are almost certainly greater than the risk of Covid.:Coronavirus: Push to prescribe vitamin D to people at highest risk from Covid in bid to curb second wave of virusParents say, rightly, that the two metre rule is not enforced in hospitals. It manestly isnrsquot in supermarkets, parks and public transport either. So why is this bureaucratic red line being applied in schools Why is the education of their children not a priority, they say  With classes and schools only able to handle a third of children, the obvious answer is to increase the number of classrooms and the number of teachers.Break out of the school precincts and start deploying unused venues like cinemas and churches, even marquees. Bring in supply teachers and retired teachers to bump up the numbers.It would of course mean more than the pound million or so in additional funding the Government is currently offering the local authorities. But the Scottish education and skills budget is more than pound. billion. Surely some of that could be reallocated, as was the case in the NHS when they set up ldquopop-up hospitals like the Louisa Jordan.At any rate, Nicola Sturgeon now has a major fight on her hands. The EIS says, correctly, that the two-metre rule is still what the Governmentrsquos scientic advisers say is necessary to prevent a second wave of Covid-. They are not going to sht on that, eventhe World Health Organisation has been talking about reducing it to one metre.There are two million parents out there and only , teachers. Ms Sturgeon can do her political arithmetic. She is going to have to spray some serious cash to get the schools back on any kind of ing basis.Scottish teachers got a  per cent pay hike from the Government last year. I suspect Mr Swinney is going to have to loosen the purse strings again to prevent the deschooling of a generation of Scottish children.The late Ivan Illich, whose thinking influenced the Curriculum for Excellence, envisaged children teaching themselves, using technology, even though he was writing before the internet existed. He would be proud to see the nationrsquos youth gathering around their screens. Unfortunately, parents arenrsquot ndash especiallyit means they lose their chances of educational qualications.Our columns are a  for writers to express their opinions. They do not necessarily represent the views of The Herald.

title: Opinion  Rosemary Goring  The Kirk s plan to banish the elderly from services is cruel  There   s no other word for it
story: The crassness of such advice beggars belief. Surely this age group can assess the risks for itself  If pews were packed as full as the Cheltenham races it might just about be defensible. Few services, however, attract high numbers. Most congregations could have upheld social distancing throughout the pandemic with no fear of catching anything worse than a cold from the draught whistling among them.:Push to prescribe vitamin D to people at highest risk from Covid in bid to curb second wave of virusMore importantly, the vast majority of the Kirkrsquos most devoted and loyal followers are over . Some will be dedicated, le-long attenders others will have reached retirement before making time to think about faith, and the search for the meaning of le.I have countless friends in their seventies and eighties who are fitter and sharper than many younger folk. It seems invidious to talk of them as a universally frail category perhaps they are better described as having reached a point when there is much less road ahead than in the rear view mirror. Yet, regardless of physical condition, by this stage spiritual sustenance and solace become more pressing and meaningful. Equally comforting is the companionship and consolation of a like-minded community.Brought up as I was in a devout Church of Scotland family, I saw the importance for older members of the routine, ritual and contact weekly services offered. Remembering some of our church-going friends, people of inspiring kindness and integrity, it is deeply upsetting to think that it is iniduals like them, to whom the church owes its very existence, who are being sidelined and devalued. The idea of banishing the elderly, of consigning them to a Zoom link or a virtual coffee morning until the virus has fled, is cruel. Therersquos no other word for it. Those for whom technology is intimidating, confusing, or a second-rate stop-gap, will be left stranded.To withdraw all prospect of real human contact is particularly egregious at a time like this. For months, the -plus have been living in near isolation and confinement, bombarded with terrying news and statistics, and unable to see family or friends. Imprisoned as they have been at home, for them the church represents a calm, still centre during the storm. Many will have been longing to get back into their place of worship, but will now be worried they are not entirely welcome. It doesnrsquot get much more hurtful than that.As well as being harsh, the Kirkrsquos attitude is also short-sighted. Dwindling as its resources are, it relies heavily on bequests. For some parishioners, as they approach old age it is important to know they will continue to contribute to the Church of Scotlandrsquos work, long after they have gone. Their legacies are priceless, not to say essential, but they should not be taken for granted. Codicils and rewrites take minutes.:Bosses warning as Scotland races ahead of other UK nations in unemploymentRegardless of the financial contribution older members have already made, to treat them so negligently is heartless. Of course nobody should fall ill because of attending a Sunday service, butsafety procedures are followed, it will be no more dangerous ndash arguably less so ndash than any other venture or visit.In showing such caution and cowardice, the Kirk has forgotten the principles on which it was founded: it is a Christian duty to tend the sick, befriend the lonely, and to nurture every believerrsquos spirit. This latest salvo smacks more of health and safety or fear of litigation than le-giving care and compassion. The Kirk has never been more necessary for all its members, butever there was a statement of its redundancy, this letter is it.Our columns are a  for writers to express their opinions. They do not necessarily represent the views of The Herald.

title: tough-decisions-ahead-cairngorm-following-years-financial-struggle
story: Caroline Gardner, the Auditor General for Scotland, said the coronavirus pandemic ldquoincreases the uncertainty around the costs and business model required for the mountain in the longer-term.Audit Scotland also called on the Scottish Government to ldquoexamine the long-term sustainability of the snow sports industry in Scotland.:We dont want your money - Shetland protests as SSE presses ahead with the UKs biggest wind farmIt follows long-running problems at the ski resort.Highlands and Islands Enterprise , a government agency, has had to step in to save it twice in the last ten years after external operators ran into financial dficulties.A new report by Audit Scotland said this ldquoraises serious questions about the sustainability of the business operating under the current model.HIE is the owner and custodian of Cairngorm Mountain, and has been responsible for its management for almost  years.However the private sector has operated the ski area for much of this time via a lease agreement.Cairngorm Mountain Ltdpreviously operated the business but struggled financially and was taken into public ownership in .In , HIE transferred the operation of Cairngorm Mountain to Natural Assets Investments Limited , which took full ownership of CML.But in September , the funicular railway ndash installed in  as part of a wider strategy to regenerate the Aviemore area ndash was closed after a routine inspection revealed structural issues, and shortly afterwards CML directors placed the company into administration.HIE again stepped in to take over the business, securing the assets and setting up Cairngorm MountainLimitedas a new subsidiary company to operate the mountain resort.Audit Scotland said it had "made progress in addressing some of the issues that arose under CML", but noted the new body generated an income of pound, between December  and the end of March , against expenditure of pound,, leaving it with a deficit of pound,.HIE is currently entangled in two legal cases ndash one relating to financial guarantees provided by NAIL and its majority shareholder, and the other concerning design and build aspects of the funicular railway.It hopes to reinstate the railway at an indicative cost of between pound million and poundm, however its plans have been delayed by the Covid- pandemic.It is also working on a masterplan for the long-term future of Cairngorm Mountain.Audit Scotlandrsquos report said local businesses and community representatives ldquoemphasised the importance of the resort in contributing to an economy that is heavily dependent on tourism.It added: ldquoIt is vitally important that HIE and the Scottish Government considers carefully the funding requirements for any future operating model, how costs will be met, and the opportunity costs of continued investment in Cairngorm Mountain and the wider snow sports industry.ldquoAny future decisions, including whether public subsidies are necessary to continue operations, must take into account not only the economic benefits that the resort can bring to the Badenoch and Strathspey area but also the community, social and environmental impacts of continuing operations.Ms Gardner said: ldquoHIE and the Scottish Government now face tough decisions on how to secure a sustainable operation at Cairngorm Mountain. The Covid- pandemic increases the uncertainty around the costs and business model required for the mountain in the longer-term.: Scottish transport giant faces legal bill after losing court case against GovernmentldquoAny future spending decisions need to be informed by the wide range of groups with an interest in the mountain.Rural Economy and Tourism Secretary Fergus Ewing welcomed the report and said its recommendations are in line with a government review carried out in . He said: ldquoCairngorm Mountain is an important natural asset and one which has the potential to provide signicant input to the Scottish economy.ldquoThe snow sports industry is an essential part of Scotlandrsquos rural economy, worth an estimated poundm per year and providing over  jobs.ldquoThrough HIE and Scottish Enterprise, the Scottish Government has made a commitment of over poundm towards infrastructure projects since .

title: former-scottish-government-adviser-says-hapless-swinney-must-go
story: Alex Bell said Mr Swinney, who has been in post six years, should have gone a long time ago and had only stayed because of the ldquopolitburo-like endurance of SNP ministers.He also claimed Mr Swinney was ldquobeholden to his cautious officials and the government bureaucracy, yet was bizarrely regarded in the party as a potential successor to Nicola Sturgeon.Writing in The Courier about the growing criticism of the Governmentrsquos schoolplans, Mr Bell said: ldquoYet again, Scotland is left looking at the education secretary and despairing."A hapless man in a serious job.ldquoWhere is John Swinneyrsquos leadership, where is his vision ndash where for that matter is Oliver Hardy, as Swinney is surely our Stan Laurel.The Scottish Tories said it underscored the SNPs "shambolic" handling of the edcucational aspect of the coronavirus pandemic.Mr Bell, who was a special adviser to Alex Salmond at the start of the SNPrsquos time in power, made his remarks as Nicola Sturgeon faces a parent backlash over theof pupils.Under the Scottish Governmentrsquos plans, pupils are due back at school from August , with physical distancing of mslashing the numbers possible in each class.Mr Swinney said last week he hoped schools would be able to deliver half their teaching time face-to-face, with the rest done at home under the lsquoblended learningrsquo model.However within hours some councils, including Edinburgh, announced a % in-school plan.Mr Swinney later said it was unlikely schools wouldto normal before summer .On Wednesday, the First Minister then downplayed blended learning - which had been the central planning assumption - as merely a ldquocontingency.In his column for the Courier, Mr Bell accused the Government of dithering and failing children while schools across Europe ed after their Covid lockdowns.He said SNP ministers appeared to be over-cautious about schools because they had been chastened by the wave of deaths in care homes on their watch.He said: ldquoScotland looks set to punish its young for the policy mistakes it made before.ldquoItrsquos too late for the care homes but thatrsquos no reason to close schools.ldquoYet again, Scotland is left looking at the education secretary and despairing.ldquoA hapless man in a serious job. But for the politburo-like endurance of SNP ministers, he should have been gone long ago.ldquoInstead he reminds us that a nationalist government scared of independence but without opposition is part of Scotlandrsquos problem, not its solution.He said that since the resignation of finance secretary Derek Mackasy in disgrace in February, Mr Swinney, who led the SNP to several election defeats from  to , was being dusted down as a potential heir to Ms Sturgeon.ldquoRemember, since Derek Mackay left under a cloud of scandal, the SNP leadership have looked to Swinney as the heir apparent to Sturgeon. Various media puffs and pro#les point to honest John as the candidate being polished for office.ldquoThat may account for Sturgeonrsquos anger on hearing of his blended learning approach.ldquoShe publicly slapped him down, saying part-time schooling would end as soon as possible.How could a man with expectations to lead be so weak, so beholden to his cautious officials and the structures of unions and local government ldquoIn truth, the idea of Swinney as leader was always daft.ldquoFor Scotlandrsquos sake, this latest blunder must have damaged the wheeze beyond repair.Mr Bell concludes: ldquoWhat Scotland needs is an education minister prepared to host the daily Covid- brie#ng to the public and able to set out the risks and realities.ldquoParents and pupils need to be engaged. consensus needs to be built. We need a minister who can encourage the same kind of love and regard for teaching as enjoyed by the NHS.ldquoA politician who can inspire rainbows and clapping.ldquoJohn Swinney has been education minister for six years. Enough is enough. Someone take charge and give our children a chance.Since leaving the Scottish Government, Mr Bell has often been a pungent critic of the SNP.After Mr Salmond was acquitted of  counts of sexual assault in March, Mr Bell, who was a defence witness at the trial, summed up his old boss as an insecure ldquocreep.He said: ldquoWhen your best defence is lsquoIrsquom sleazy but not criminalrsquo, itrsquos nothing to smile about.Scottish Conservative education spokesmanJamie Greene said:ldquoThe SNPrsquos handling of education throughout this crisis has been shambolic.ldquoIt knew since March that this problem was coming down the tracks, and several months on therersquos still no plan which parents can rely on or trust.ldquoParents and teachers are furious with the Scottish Government over this, and itrsquos no wonder John Swinney is now facing this level of criticism.ldquoWe need to see some more creative thinking, yet all we get from the SNP is real poverty of ambition and imagination.ldquoItrsquos been a tough few months for everyone, but the SNP now risks turning this into an irreversible catastrophe for an entire generation.An SNP spokesman said: ldquoThere will always be people who snipe from the side lines. The Deputy First Minister is busy getting on with his job."

title: phase-2-13-new-changes-scotlands-lockdown-restrictions-eased
story: Throughout the last week, the First Minister had indicated her optimism at moving the country into Phase  of the four-phased route map out of lockdown restrictions.The decision was made at the three-weekly formal review of the measures, following a further suppression of the coronavirus in Scotland ndash with the NRS revealing yesterday the number of virus-related deaths fell for the seventh week in a row.But what does Phase  actually mean for you From seeing family and friends to outdoor shopping, here are the biggest changes from the latest easing of lockdown.Shielding peopleFrom today, people who are shielding can go outdoors for exercise.Shielding people can also take part in non-contact outdoor activity, such as golf, from tomorrow.From tomorrow, people who are shielding can also meet people from one other household.Seeing friends and familyThe First Minister today revealed people can enter other households to use the toilet - but should continue meeting outdoors.You will also be able to meet with larger groups including family and friends outside - with the maximum of  extra households and  people.This is in addition to the measures from Phase , which included sunbathing sitting outdoors, and visiting other households outdoors and in gardens.Extended householdFrom tomorrow, people who live alone or with children under  can have a bubble with one other household - you can visit indoors and stay overnight.This has to be with this household onlyTransportPublic transport can increase their capacity but will remain signicantly limited to allow for physical distancing.Face masks will be mandatory on all public transport.The First Minister says the five mile limit for leisure and recreational purposes will remain for now - "remain as close as possible to local area" until Phase There is no five-mile limit for visiting family and friends.DentistsAll dental practices can reopen to see patients with urgent care needs from Phase  ndash meanwhile procedures which generate aerosols will remain at emergency dental hubs.SportsThe guidance also says the resumption of professional sport, in line with public health advice, is allowed.As with the previous Phase, unrestricted outdoors exercise is permitted, so long as you adhere to distancing measures. Non-contact sports like golf, hiking, fishing etc remain allowed.However, gyms will not be able to reopen until Phase .WorshipThe route map also says places of worship will be able to reopen for private prayer - but not for extended groups until Phase .ShoppingOutdoor markets can also reopen, provided there can be controls on the number of people within the market and distancing is kept.The First Minister also outlined plans fornon-essential retail units to reopen form June - but these will have to have outside entrances. Therefore shopping centres cannot reopen.Drive-thrus and garden centres were already permitted to reopen under the previous easing of measures.SportsSports courts and playgrounds are now permitted to reopen across Scotland.WorkingWorking from home remains the default position.But the guidance says non-essential indoor, non-office based workplaces can reopen - including factories, warehouses, lab and research facilities.The construction sector can also implement further stages of a phased .There can also be a relaxation of restriction on housing moves.MarriagesMoving houseRelaxation on restrictions on housing moves.EducationCollege and university staff canto make essential preparations for restart in Phase .These institutionswill not until Phase , with schools set toacross Scotland from August .

title: nicola-sturgeon-shops-reopen-june-29-amid-easing-restrictions
story: But the First Minister said she is not yet able to give a date for the reopening of outdoor hospitality such as beer gardens, with a further update due around July .Ms Sturgeon said more people will be able to meet up and use toilets in other households from tomorrow, while masks will be made compulsory on public transport from Monday.Anyone who lives on their own - or only with children under  - will also be able to form an lsquoextended household grouprsquo with one other household.Within an extended household group, people will be able to meet indoors without physical distancing, as well as staying overnight.But they must continue to see any other households outdoors only, and stay more than twometres apart from them.Ms Sturgeon said she hoped this would help ease"some of the isolation which is one of the cruellest consequences of tackling this virus".Addressing MSPs in Holyrood, she also outlined further measures.She said: "From tomorrow, people from one household can meet outdoors with people from up to twoother households."You can meet these two households together or separately and it doesnrsquot always have to be the same households - but it should be no more than twoat a time and no more than twoin a day."And we are still advising no more than eightin any group."We will also change the guidance so that you can,necessary, go indoors to use the toiletyou are meeting in the garden of another household."Shops of all sizes are due to reopen from June , alongside outdoor markets,zoos andgarden attractions.However indoor shopping centres will remain closed,except for access to essential shops such as supermarkets and pharmacists.Some indoor workplaces that have so far opted to remain closed in line with guidance - such as factories, labs and warehouses ndash can also start to reopen from this date.Professional sport will resume behind closed doors fromJune .Dentists will also be able to re-open on this date, initially for urgent care, while places of worship canreopen for inidual prayer.Meanwhile, face coverings will become mandatory on public transport ndash such as trains, buses and taxis ndash from this Monday.Children under five, those with breathing dficulties and those with physical conditions which make it hard to keep the mask in place will be exempted.Ms Sturgeon said: "I understand the desire of all businesses to reopen quickly ndash however it is vital than when services and venues do reopen, they do so safely and in a way that is consistent with continued suppression of the virus."The First Minister said the two-metre physical distancing rule remains in place.But she added: "However, I have asked our advisers to consider whether there are particular settings and circumstances in which, with additional mitigations, it might be possible in future to recommend a distance of  or . metres."Many businesses such as bars and restaurants have saidthey will not be able to operate under the two-metre rule.Elsewhere, Ms Sturgeon announced updated measures for those who are shielding, allowing them to go outdoors for exercise from today.From tomorrow, they can also take part in non-contact outdoor activities such as golf.She added: "In addition, the advice from tomorrow will be that people who are shielding can meet outdoors with people from one other household ndash but in groups of no more than eight."However,you are shielding, you should continue to be extremely cautious."That means staying at least twometres away from other people at all times, evenyou live with the person yoursquore out with."Do not go inside someone rsquos house, or allow someone from another household to go inside yours, even to use the toilet."And when you go outside, choose times and areas that are quiet. And wash your hands thoroughly as soon as you get back home."

title: major-u-turn-uk-government-abandons-attempt-build-covid-19-tracing-app
story: The major U-turn saw the Department of Health and Social Care announce that efforts would instead be targeted on developing a programme which supports the NHS Test and Trace service based on Apple and Googles model.No datehas been set for the roll-out, despite Health Secretary Matt Hancock previously said the key app would be available in mid-May.:This simple tool shows the tragic COVID- death toll where you liveOfficials said the Governmentrsquos app, which was being trialled on the Isle of Wight, was highly inaccurate when used on iPhones, only identying around % of contacts.They said they hoped to feed their research into the Google-Apple project, suggesting that the trialled app is superior when dealing with distances between iniduals.Baroness Harding, the executive chair of NHS Test and Trace and Matthew Gould, the chief executive of the NHSX technology wing of the health service, said there had been ldquospecic technical challenges.ldquoOur response to this virus has and will continue to be as part of an international effort, they said in a joint statement.:Shops to reopen from June  amid further easing of restrictionsldquoThat is why as part of a collaborative approach we have agreed to share our own innovative work on estimating distance between app users with Google and Apple, work that we hope will benefit others, while using their solution to address some of the specic technical challenges identied through our rigorous testing.

title: snp-revisit-plans-pause-indyref2-uk-governments-refusal-brexit-compromise
story: The Scottish Governmentrsquos Constitution Secretary has criticised Boris Johnsonrsquos Government for what he claimed was a lack of engagement with the devolved UK nations over the Brexit deadline.The transition period will expire at the end of . Last week, Michael Gove confirmed the UK Government will not ask for an extension, hours before a scheduled meeting with Nicola Sturgeon and Welsh counterparts.The Scottish Government announced in March it would postpone planning for another independence referendum in , an issue that was key to the SNP election campaign in .Following the  general election, the Scottish Government requested the powers to hold a second independence referendum, which was unsurprisingly rejected by the Prime Minister.:Nicola Sturgeon formally drops plan for Indyref this yearMr Russell told MSPs that the UK Government has refused to compromise on seeking an extension to the December  date for the end of the transition period with the EU, in contrast to the way the Scottish Government has on Scottish independence.He added: "The fact that theyve refused to do so shows me that the compromise that we have taken in order to ensure that all our resources are focused on Covid- is something we will need to revisit."The Cabinet minister said this is "one of the bigger impacts you can have on the economy" without the risk of the increased spread of coronavirus.:Post-Brexit trade talks will not be extended after  despite Nicola Sturgeons warningHe questioned the timing of the Brexit process, which is expected coincide with a recovery from one of the worst recessions in recorded history due to the Covid- pandemic.Mr Russell said: "If you accept that is the case, what type of insanity would then lead you to suppose you could pile on an additional hit to GDP "The only reason for doing it would be because ideologically youre fixated by this or because you think you can hide the damage from Brexit under worse damage being done by something ."Mr Russell also criticised the Joint Ministerial Committee, which brings together officials from the devolved administrations and UK Government to discuss common issues.:Blackford: Best Brexit deal for Scotland is independenceA separate sub-committee has been set up specically for the EU negotiations.He said a number of ideas were put forward by the devolved countries but "zilch" was offered by the UK Government.Mr Russell said: "Weve brought ideas to the table, weve talked about them, weve published them."You have zilch from the UK Government. There is no commitment to change, no matter what is said."I believe there is a deep-rooted hostility to devolution and a view of the supremacy of Westminster that I believe cant be changed."

title: scottish-government-advisors-have-no-idea-evidence-lockdown-decisions-coming-from
story: Linda Bauld, Professor of Public Health at Edinburgh University, praised Nicola Sturgeons handling of information during the coronavirus pandemic but said the basis for some decisions had been unclear.The academic was speaking to MPs at the Scottish Affairs Committee in Westminster this afternoon where she said that the First Minister was "far better" at communicating and being "able to say where a decision has come from" than the UK Government had been.However she added: "I think some of their more recent decisions about the pace are really unclear to me. For example, we heard today that the hospitality venues that can operate outdoors are not going to be able to do that in the near future in Scotland, which I think is going to cause a lot of problems for that sector.ldquoSome of the other decisions around releasing of lockdown, and also the point that [was made] about some of the inconsistencies in the details and the advice, I have no idea where these are coming from.ldquoAnd to be perfectly frank, when Ive spoken to some of my colleagues who sit on the advisory group, its not obvious where theyre coming from. So not everything has been transparent, at all.Professor Bauld was joined by Akash Paun, Senior Fellow at the Institute for Government, Professor Nicola McEwen, Co-Director at the Centre of Constitutional Change and Professor David Bell a Professor of Economics at the University of Stirling During the session.Mr Paun said the Scottish Governments approach to information sharing was one that Westminster "could learn from" and added: " Theres a greater degree of transparency about the Scottish Governments decision making approach. I dont say that with any party-political hats on but I think theres been a greater openness the UK Government could learn from."Professor Bell warned that Scotland was going to see further coronavirus outbreaks similar to that currently in Beijing "pretty soon", and suggested that further work needed to be done to allow people to make quick decisions to tackle the spread of the virus.He said: "Both governments have a very dficult task to go from an extreme lockdown to one by where they need to encourage people to get out into the community start interacting again...Im pretty sure were going to get outbreaks pretty soon in similar ways to the one that just occurred in China."It does seem to me that that you have to empower people at a local level to take quick decisions. Thats not necessarily at the level of the UK Government to the Scottish Government, it may be at a lower level still."The witnesses were asked whether the coronavirus crisis might provide a "" to improve relationships between the Scottish and UK Governments.Professor McEwen said she was "pessimistic" over whether progress would be made, and cited Brexit and Independence as reasons for problems, adding that there had "been a lack of trust and lack of awareness of devolution in Whitehall".The Scotland Office, headed up by Alister Jack also came in for criticism with Mr Paun telling MPs the office served as a centre for "institutional memory about the Scottish devolution settlement".He said: "The Scotland office, it does serve awithin Whitehall as a centre of expertise to some extent, or institutional memory perhaps, about the Scottish devolution settlement. It holds contacts, relationships networks in Scotland that can prove useful to some extent to other departments, but it has never, or not for some time, been a central player in managing intergovernmental relations."

title: coronavirus-scotlands-slow-steady-exit-already-working
story: As she outlined a staged approach to Phase  that has delayed any change to physical distancing for now and kicked the re-opening of beer gardens into the long grass, the First Minister told MSPs that "patience could reap our greatest rewards"."The prize for going more slowly now is a recovery that is much more sustainable and one that will, I hope, allow more normality toto our daily lives," said Ms Sturgeon.: A guide to some of Scotlands best beer gardensSince the UK began moving out of lockdown, Scotland has generally moved at a slightly slower pace: overall, we spent longer under lockdown, our schools remain closed, and non-essential shops will have to wait two weeks longer than Englands to re-open.One potentially interesting trend has emerged already.For most of May, both Scotland and England were recording roughly the same Covid death rate per day: in both countries it tracked steadily downwards from seven per million population around May  to around four per million by the end of May.Since then, however, the trajectory has split, with Scotland declining faster to fewer than one Covid death per day for every million people, while Englands is around three per million.How much that is down to the social distancing measures in place, or simply the populations compliance with them health experts said risked eroding the publics cooperation is impossible to say.But it appears that the goal for Ms Sturgeon is not just to suppress the virus but to get as close as possible to eradicating it.Stringent social distancing, contact tracing and quarantining snuffed out SARS  years ago. New Zealand has achieved much the same with Covid: it had had no new cases at all for  days, until two UK visitors tested positive this week.The lower the prevalence of the virus within the population, the easier it is to pinpoint and contain new clusters, prevent a second wave and allow a fullerto normalityalbeit at a later date.Whatever our progress, Scotland recorded  new cases between May  and June , so eradication is still elusive.: Why the science has no clear-cut answers to Scotlands two-metre dilemmaIn this context, the decision not to re-open beer gardens is all about a better result later: for example, reducing virus prevalence enough that physical distancing can be halved to one metre in time for the hospitality traderesuming on July .Ms Sturgeon said there is emerging evidence that pubs, restaurants and gyms are "hotspots for transmission". Japanese research found that the risk of infection is around  times higher indoors than outdoors.So why is it safe to open outdoor food markets but not beer gardens  One theory is that people in beer gardens spend a prolonged period in same company, increasing the risk of transmissionsomeone in the group is infected but not yet showing symptoms.They are also more likely to talk loudly, shout, or even singwhich is also linked to transmission.
